updates.update_content:
Hey everyone
Long time no speak – and apologies if you're reading this message on several of my projects you've backed. 
I'm writing to let you know that I'm changing my Kickstarter profile name from Max Leonard ––> Isola Press.

updates.update_userinfo: New rough stuff book – 24 hours of earlybird discount left
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone
Hope you don't mind me getting in touch quickly, but I recently launched a new Isola Press book on Kickstarter… it's going very well, and there's around 24 hours left to receive the earlybird discount.

A very quick update, as we've got an awful lot of books to send out… but they arrived this morning (a day late, but hey), and they look amazing.
We're really really pleased. 
Here's a few pics for you, while you wait for your order. (There will be more on my Instagrams – @m_xl and @isolapress – because the upload here is painful).

Hi everyone
A short update to let you know we sent the final files to the printer today. That means we're in good time to be ready to print next Wednesday (23rd May), and as it stands the finished product is set for delivery (to us) on 4th June,. 
So we'll be sending them out from the 5th. Might take a few days for us to get through all the orders!

Hey folks,
Stefan here, fresh off the back of a weekend drawing! I'm pleased to say I've finally finished the overview map and A3 print for the Rough Stuff Alps project. For the backers that went for the limited edition print, thanks, I really hope you like it. 
Apologies for the time it took to see a finished visual. These things take time: time to get my head around layouts, scales, level of detail; time to work out what would work for the book and also as a print that people might hang in their house (or loo...); time to set aside to actually draw...

updates.update_userinfo: “(tricky if under snow)” – some notes from the copy edit…
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone
Everything is going well and I'm deep inside the copy edit of Fred Wright's work at the moment – a pretty straightforward task, actually, as he worked as a proofreader at the Cambridge University Press, so the manuscript is of a very high standard! 
But it gives me a chance to read everything and get under the skin of his writing. I like it because, even though the style might seem a little old fashioned, it is succinct and precise. And, despite the brevity, full of character.

updates.update_userinfo: Adding routes to the Rough Stuff guide
updates.update_content:
Happy Easter everyone!
A quick update to say that I am very pleased that Will Davis, the man behind the website Cycling-Challenge.com, has agreed to contribute some routes to the new edition of the guide. 
If you don't know the site, you should: it's full of amazing info on paved and unpaved routes through the Alps.

Hi everyone
A short note to say thanks again for the outstanding support for this project. 
I really wanted to get Rough Stuff Cycling in the Alps republished, so I set the minimum print run low. I suspected there would be a few people who would be interested in seeing it too, but I was totally blown away by the level of response.

Book arrived, great production, really enjoying reading it.
Many thanks, book arrived today and love it!
Heard about this on The Bike Show. Excited to be a part. Good luck with next stages of publishing.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The weather is a capricious friend: To capture all the great moments for Salted in Germany, we are always searching for extraordinary light and atmosphere. In the recent years we had rainy summers in Germany, so our travel through the country will depending on weather situations. To have enough time to write, assemble and design the book, we are planning to travel the country in May. Even if a part will be done in July, we will be able to finish the book until the end of October to be sure to have the printed copies ready to deliver in the end of November. One month for printing includes a slack time of 2 weeks for complications in printing and binding process, material or final delivery. We ambitiously try to deliver books before Christmas holidays! 

From the point our project is funded, Lauren will start writing introducing chapters to the parts we want to travel to. Finalized with the stories and recipes we collected on our journey, she will be co-working with Pepe during the designing period. Pepe will be working full time for the project, when the travels are done.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
NOTE: The 2018 Black History Month Theme is "African Americans in Times of War."
(Sources include: Wikipedia, The Atlantic, NPR, ABC News)
  The Colored Boys of Uncle Sam, Limited Edition
 THE COLORED BOYS OF UNCLE SAM
As an African-American VFW, I am always surprised to hear some of the epic, untold stories about African-American veterans. As a journalist, I feel an obligation to help these veterans reach a mass audience so that they can share their stories and inspire children, especially African-Americans, to serve their country for the greater good.
Harlem Hellfighters in Trenches
THESE EPIC STORIES MUST BE TOLD
Generally, these are stories about all the decorated (by France and, not until recently, the United States) African-American soldiers of World War I – those 400,000 men who braved their own country’s stereotypes in order to fight the enemy. Specifically, we feature the men of the 369th, the "Harlem Hellfighters." If you’re expecting a "woe is me" story, you won’t find it here. You will find an exciting coffee table read about the bravery and heroism of these men whom France honored when America would not.
I will write the stories, as well as collect, catalog, and audit content to make these incredible photographs and tales available in one unique book that you can own and share. It’ll be a rare addition to your personal collection.
The stories will be fully researched and vetted. For example:
The most celebrated man in the 369th was Pvt. Henry Johnson, a former Albany, New York rail station porter who earned the nickname "Black Death" for his combat actions in France. In May 1918, Johnson and Pvt. Needham Roberts fought off a 24-man German patrol, though both were severely wounded. After they expended their ammunition, Roberts used his rifle as a club and Johnson battled with a bolo knife. Reports suggest that Johnson killed at least four German soldiers and might have wounded 30 others.
While overseas, the 369th Regiment made up less than 1% of the soldiers deployed but was responsible for over 20% of the land territory assigned to the United States.
During the war, the 369th's regimental band became famous throughout Europe. It introduced a strange new music, called "Jazz," to British, French, and other European audiences.
On December 13, 1918, one month after Armistice Day, the French government awarded the Croix de Guerre to 170 individual members of the 369th. The entire regiment received a unit citation.
These stories were deliberately kept hidden from American citizens because of racism during that time. Today, they shed light on the true heroism of African-Americans – heroism that France, Great Britain, and even the German soldiers came to know and admire.
The nickname "Men of Bronze" was given to the regiment by the French. The nickname "Hellfighters" was given to them by the Germans due to their toughness and the fact that they never lost a man through capture, nor did they lose a trench or a foot of ground to the enemy!
The enemy tried heavily to recruit the "Hellfighters," though because of these men's loyalty to the United States, the enemy failed.
Harlem Hellfighters with French
We're shedding light on the truth of their journey so that more African-American children can be proud of their heritage of service to the country. More researchers, teachers, and students can learn from these stories and keep their fighting spirit alive.
This real history is as exciting as a #wakandaforever #blackpanther movie superhero.
Although the book itself is a collector’s item full of rare photographs and a collection of rarely shared stories, I am also including a collectible coin to commemorate the centennial celebrations this year.
This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to obtain this rare gold coin, which will never be offered anywhere else again.
Advance Release:
Order Your New 2018 Collectible Gold Coin Now!
Minted by United State Military Veterans, with the finest quality.
New 2018 Collectible Gold Coin
Although this book can stand on its own, I have put together a team of professionals with expert credentials to offer you a unique collectible coin that celebrates this amazing group of young men.
Our coin will be minted by Coins For Anything (https://coinsforanything.com), which is America's largest veteran owned custom coin company, founded by former Marine, Jeff Morin.
Coin Size Comparison
Millions of people collect gold coins. Right now, they are lining up to collect the hottest new coins. Today, you can be at the front of the line by reserving your own 2018 collectible gold coin in uncirculated condition, before millions of others beat you to it.
This 1.5-inch antique gold coin, minted in the United States by veterans, is 3.5mm thick—0.5mm thicker than other minted coins. This increased thickness allows these 3D coins to display the sharpest detail and imagery in the industry, making them remarkable one-of-a-kind collectables. This is perhaps the best quality that the industry has to offer.
Limited Edition Canvas Print:
3D Canvas Print
  Sponsor Large Art Exhibit
      Author Tony Reynolds
Tony Reynolds and his work have appeared in hundreds of nationally known media outlets. He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Journalism/Public Relations from The Ohio State University.
Reynolds is media savvy and has written several successful books, including “Buster’s Backyard Bar-B-Q, Knockout Diabetes Diet,” with former World Heavyweight Boxing Champion James “Buster” Douglas.
He has also produced television shows for Universal Sports Network and the Versus Network (now known as NBC Sports).
He and his work have been featured by ABC News Now, the Associated Press, Billboard Magazine, Bloomberg, ESPN, Fox News, Fox Soccer, Forbes.com, The History Channel, ManCow Muller, Oprah, Martha Stewart Sirius Radio, Reuters,USA Today.com, the Versus Network (now known as NBC Sports), The Wall Street Journal, ABC, CBS, Fox and NBC affiliates, and most known media. He was featured on the first-ever 3D broadcast for ESPN.
Author Tony Reynolds Center
This is a picture from basic training. That's me in the center, standing, with Stack on the left. I had just cracked a joke and gotten Ernie to laugh. On this day, I didn't realize that Stack and I were standing on the shoulders of the brave men of the 369th. Their LOYALTY and sacrifice opened the door for other African-American men, like us, to be invited to serve this great nation. We owe them a debt of gratitude.
Author Tony Reynolds
I respectfully request your support to contribute to bring this project to life. I promise you will not be disappointed!
Share Something Epic on Facebook
    Share an Epic Tweet!
  PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS:
COINS FOR ANYTHING -
The United States World War I Centennial Commission

All of the books images are licensed under a common license, so all of the backing material is available.

With that being said, there is a risk the book will not be completed if I befall some untimely demise.

campaign.story:
Three years ago, I had an idea to make a book. That idea grew from a few illustrations that followed a Japanese folk song full narrative and the idea of printing the whole thing with letterpress. Because of Kickstarter, I made that book a reality.
Shortly after the campaign ended, I had an idea for another book. I've been working on that for the past two years.
Tamaishi is about a little pebble who gets the idea to be something he's not, eventually discovering that its better to just be who you are. He travels far and wide across the valley where the little things live, to the ancient forest of Niwaki, and gets lost in the Great Sea.Read the first chapter!
I use Ulysses for writing
   So what are you making?
Three editions of Tamaishi — preliminary cover design
There are three goals: a softcover edition, an audiobook, and a casebound edition. The book is printed using black and spot color on a Ryobi 2-color press. I plan on using black + a blue PMS and black + green PMS for different parts of the book as they have different moods. 
I'm still working on recording the audiobook, so I don't have an example just yet. But if you want to know what it might sound like, check out the 3-minute sample of my last book Zōsan on soundcloud.
Examples of spot color art!
Also available are 1-color letterpress prints — and a limited run of hand-watercolor painted prints: For a sampler of all the artwork, please see this blog post. Letterpress prints will be available for the 14 "full plate" (6x8) artwork. 
Watercolor example (not the final rendering — each unique!)
So how's this going to work?
If successfully funded, I'll start making final steps towards production. I'll wrap up the writing and continue ahead with the audiobook recording and editing. I'll work on composing all the music for the audiobook. 
I'll get the plates made for letterpress prints and I'll work with the offset press to determine the final paper choices and PMS spot colors. I'll begin ordering necessary materials for casebound books: bookcloth, end sheets, headbands, cover stock, etc. Then I'll let them do their thing while I work on the audiobook and prepare for shipping.
Zōsan was such a joy to behold in its final forms. I hope you'll join me in making this next book a reality as well.
—¡™
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I've been here before. I know the printers and binder and I've been communicating with them for months about this. I know the costs and what it's going to take — and my funding goal reflects that.

The project is small enough that I can single-handedly manage the fulfillment process. It's actually smaller than the non-profit publication process I used to run a while back (hundreds of books all shipped from Canada) — so no worries there!

The audiobook music will be a bit more of a challenge than the last time, since I don't have a folk song melody to work from, but now that the artwork and writing are mostly finished I can concentrate on that.


If you have any doubts, please take a quick look at Zōsan! I can't guarantee there will be zero delays, this being an artistic process — but I have a vested interest in seeing this done, (I want one!!) so I can guarantee it will be made.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Where All the Little Things Live reached 100% funding! 💯 🎈🌨
updates.update_content:
Just this past weekend, my new book was successfully funded on Kickstarter. It’s now at 102%, which means it’s on its way to the printers in the coming weeks.
There’s still time to pledge and get a copy: there are two letterpress editions added in celebration of being fully funded, and if I hit 111% (like both my other books did) I’ll add circular magnets as a reward for all book backers. The campaign ends in just a few days — July 13, 2020.

updates.update_userinfo: Where All the Little Things Live is 46% funded, one week in!
updates.update_content: Dear Tamaishi Backers —

updates.update_userinfo: New Kickstarter Live! Where All the Little Things Live
updates.update_content:
All of you helped me bring Tamaishi to life. Since then I've been in a number of local author events and continued to sell books and connect with other authors & readers. 
I couldn't have gotten here without all of your support!
I am busy on new projects, with a goal to complete a follow up collection of short stories in the world of Tamaishi.

Nearly all the books and rewards have been put in the mail, including the sketches to Finland and Sweden and other parts of the country!
The only rewards that remain are a handful of letterpress end sheet books. Those new end sheets have been printed and they look much better. They're being shipped to the binder this week, and the books should be done sometime in February.
What's next?

… if you need to update your address.
Unless you can find your original survey email, in which case I think you can use it to update.
But if you send a message I’ll get it in the same thread and I’ll update my records.

campaign.story:
This is a mock-up of the cover.
About Backstage at The Lost Colony
Much has been written about The Lost Colony outdoor drama and the historical event that inspired it, but Backstage at The Lost Colony is the first book to go behind the scenes to offer a view of the show the audience never sees—the grinding toil, the artistic vision, the occasional mishaps, the moments of mischief and glimpses of grace. With the relaunch of our Kickstarter campaign, we have revised our offering from a paperback book to a hardcover limited edition--a true collector's item you'll be proud to display.
The book is more than 170 pages, with more than 100 photos, mostly color, by photographers such as Delena Gray Ostrander, Eden Saunders, Duane Cochran, and Jamil Zraikat. The core narrative, by former cast member Dwayne Walls, follows the cast and crew through The Lost Colony's 80th anniversary season. His observations are supplemented by first-person stories from Colony alumni.
The Contents Page
  The book discusses the show's founding and major milestones.
  A group photo from the 80th reunion is one of many photos featuring alumni
    About The Lost Colony outdoor drama
For eight decades, The Lost Colony has defied the odds. From its improbable founding during the Great Depression, through flood and fires, playwright Paul Green’s first and most famous symphonic outdoor drama is a study in resilience. And like the "lost" colonists of Roanoke Island, the people who created and sustained The Lost Colony—and who continue to preserve its legacy—are a study in passion and determination.
Our fondest wish is that you will support our passion project AND take in a performance of The Lost Colony during its 81st season.
About the Author
The son of a journalist, Dwayne Walls Jr. is uniquely suited to tell the Backstage story. He first signed on with The Lost Colony as a 19 year-old actor technician—a hapless “space puppy” who was too preoccupied with the itch of his colonist’s beard and the paucity of his paycheck to enjoy his first summer with the show. But he returned a few years later with a different outlook and, even though his beard still itched, he grew both professionally and personally. Through his experience with The Lost Colony, Dwayne developed an enduring appreciation for the work and the workers behind the scenes, which is evident in the story he tells. After leaving The Lost Colony, Dwayne went on to New York City to build sets for theater, film, and television—including NBC’s Saturday Night Live. These days, he lives with his wife Elizabeth in Pittsboro, North Carolina, where he remains a member in good standing of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees Local One.
Photo of Dwayne Walls Jr. by Frederick V. Nielsen II
How We'll Use the Funds
We plan to use the funds we raise to help offset the cost of printing a hardbound limited edition. The costs of pre-press and printing and shipping is more than $15,000. We hope you will share in bringing our project to life!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have been working on this book since early 2016, when we first posted a Facebook page announcing our intention to the Lost Colony community, which showed enthusiastic support right from the beginning (thank you!). The book has been written, edited, designed, and is currently in production. It will go to print in early March. It is being printed in the U.S.A.

We're on schedule to have copies in hand for The Lost Colony's 2018 Opening Night (May 25). We are far enough along in the process to feel confident in our schedule.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
With the help of hundreds of people, including YOU, Backstage at The Lost Colony was officially released yesterday with launch festivities on Roanoke Island. We have the benefit of fantastic media coverage, including feature stories in the three most widely circulated Outer Banks visitor publications, and it's helping to spur strong sales out of the gate. Check out the photos below!
It was great to see so many supporters yesterday and give out books along with a face-to-face thank you. Dwayne has been busy signing!

It's a gorgeous, sunny day in Virginia, and my day was made even brighter by the sight of a big envelope from the printer that contained proofs of the covers to Backstage at The Lost Colony. They're beautiful! I can't find a single flaw, and I have the comfort of knowing my terrific design and production team is looking over them as well. Only about six weeks now until the launch celebrations! I can't wait to get the book to you and hope you'll share your feedback when you see it.
Thank you for your faith in our project!

Our Kickstarter campaign ended at midnight at 120 percent of goal, thanks to your generous pledges. Dwayne Walls and I are incredibly grateful for your enthusiasm and support--so essential to this project.
What happens now?
In the next few days, I'll send a survey to collect the details necessary to fulfill your rewards. The files are at the printer in Illinois, and I'll have copies of both the hardcover and the paperback in hand for 's opening weekend festivities May 25-26. Our launch activities, including a book signing at Waterside Theatre, will be on Saturday, May 26. If you live on the Outer Banks or plan to visit then, that will be the earliest opportunity to get your book. For those who can't make it then, we'll ship the first week in June via Media Mail.

I couldn't be happier to announce that, thanks to each and every one of you, we just reached our goal on Kickstarter.
I'm already thinking about a new reward for a stretch goal, since we have more than a week to go. More on that in the next few days. For those who aren't familiar with Kickstarter, projects often offer extra rewards for all backers if the project reaches certain stretch goals.

I'm pleased to be able to announce the details of our book launch events. There will be two on Saturday, May 26:
CELEBRATION AND BOOK SIGNING AT WATERSIDE THEATRE: A book signing hosted by The Lost Colony at Waterside Theatre, beginning at 6 p.m. and running until just before the show begins at 7:45. The author, Dwayne Walls, will give a reading, and members of the artistic staff will be available to answer questions about the show. We'll have light refreshments, and beer and wine will be available at the concession stand. This is a perfect time to see the show and pick up your copy of the book at the same time! We're indebted to the Roanoke Island Historical Association for the opportunity to showcase the book during 's Opening Weekend celebrations!

In honor of all the talented young people who begin their careers in the performing arts at The Lost Colony, we just confirmed plans to offer a paperback edition of the book. It will retail for $24.99, and we're offering it on Kickstarter for $20 plus shipping. 
We're moving steadily toward our goal--thank you for helping us get there! Please help us get the word out by sharing our campaign and updates with your friends.
Barbara

We're excited to announce that Outer Banks Magazine will feature Backstage at The Lost Colony in its summer edition. If you're not familiar with it, it's a glossy lifestyle magazine with a long shelf life, and the exposure will be great for the book and the show!
With two weeks to go in our Kickstarter campaign, we've added another reward: "Queen's Garden Party," offering an autographed copy of the book, an invitation for two to the VIP launch party on May 26, and two premier tickets to the show, including a private backstage tour. And in case you didn't see it last week, we added an option for two copies of the book, which had been requested by a backer. Thank you for your interest, support, and suggestions!

Okay, I'm still working out the details of the launch festivities and can't share them quite yet, but I encourage you to block the weekend of May 25 and make sure you have a place to stay on Roanoke Island if you don't live there already. (Shoot me a note if you need advice on a place to stay. Got you covered.) That's opening weekend for the show, and we're coordinating with the Colony and others so you can immerse yourself in the best of what Roanoke Island has to offer without missing a thing. Stay tuned!
In the meantime, I promised one of our earliest backers I would post this picture, which shows her son, Landon Ferrell, as the Master of the Queen's Ceremonies (far left). I get what it's like to be a proud mama--this one's for you, Melissa!

campaign.story:
Joe De Yong (1894 - 1975)
 About the Book
“Joe De Yong: A Life in the West” is the story of a passionate cowboy's life in the America West during the first part of the last century. Over ten years of research has revealed the life of a relatively unknown artist/illustrator who started out to be “just a cowboy." Turns out, Joe De Yong was quite a "mover and shaker" who touched the lives of so many in the western art world of the 1920s through the late 1960s. His was a life of challenges, including overcoming cerebral meningitis in 1913 that left him totally deaf. Never one for self-pity, De Yong went on to become the only protégé of his artistic hero - the legendary Montana artist, Charles M. Russell.  He would take the skills he learned and make a life in the movie business working with Cecil B. DeMille and many others.
Joe De Yong sketching in the Judith Basin, Montana
This is a grand, untold story and the goal here is to raise the funding to get the book to print and into your hands. All the research, photography has been done and paid for; the money raised on Kickstarter will go to printing books and shipping them to readers.
De Yong costume sketch - 1938
How You Can Help.
Joe DeYong’s story is an important one in the history of the art and culture of the American West. Your funding of $50.00 or more assures you a signed copy of this effort. Together we can bring Joe’s story to life.
About Joe DeYong (1894 – 1975)
Joseph Franklin De Yong was born in Webster Groves, Missouri, a suburb of St. Louis. He had an immediate attraction to the cowboy way of life and when he was not at school he would help out a local ranches. If he wasn’t riding he was sketching the subjects he loved the most – cowboys and horses. At 13 years of age, he started working a local ranch when he heard a movie was being made in the area and they need cowboys. He jumped at the chance and met the silent-screen's ultimate cowboy of the day, Tom Mix. Joe was hit with the idea of acting in moving pictures and followed the film company to Arizona in 1913. Somehow he came down with what was called at the time “cerebral meningitis” which would leave him totally deaf.
Joe De Yong, 1919
Undeterred and further focused on his love of the cowboy ways, De Yong recuperated by traveling the West - including seeing in an exhibit in Wyoming of the works of the renowned artist, Charles M. Russell. The exhibit stopped young Joe in his tracks and he started writing to Russell resulting in Joe’s opportunity to move to Great Falls, Montana in late 1914 to work with Russell in his studio. De Yong would be the first and only protégé of Russell’s staying with him - and his wife Nancy Russell - until CM Russell’s death in 1926. De Yong moved to Santa Barbara, CA at the urging of Russell and his mutual friend, artist Edward Borein. Borein would introduce De Yong to people in his circle that led to a meeting with film producer Cecil B. DeMille. De Yong would go on to a diverse career in the movie business, writing and creating artwork until his death in 1975. Joe De Yong contributed much to the fabric of the cultural West and most importantly brought people together to understand and appreciate the need for authenticity and detail in the representation of the pre-1900, American West. A West that both he and Russell knew was rapidly disappearing. After Russell’s death, De Yong dedicated his life to making sure the West he and Russell loved would not be forgotten.
About the book
  Alice and Will James (left) with Joe De Yong at right.
◊ case bound with dust jacket
◊ Hundreds of full color rare and many, never seen photographs, artworks, sketches by Joe De Yong. Many letters, articles and notes – most in Joe’s own hand will be included.
◊ Page count – over 300 pages
◊ The book will be published and marketed by the author’s imprint, Alamar Media.
Thank You. I am deeply grateful to everyone who has stopped by and supported this important project about a significant American and Western artist. Thank you.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are few challenges in the publishing of this book as all the hard and truly expensive parts are finished. The book is researched, photos and artwork collected, all usage fees paid along with all the travel and interviews done along the way. We are raising the funds in order to get the presses started and ship books. The only real risk is we don't raise the needed funds. I have indicated $15,000 as the amount to be raised which is the major part of the printings costs - and I will pay the balance - already put aside. I feel it's a must for me to have skin in the game beyond just the writing and the research. You can contact me at anytime as I will be giving updates on the process.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.title: HARDCOVER EDITION
support.descp: You'll receive a signed-by-the-author copy of the book. We will be doing a limited printing, so this will guarantee you get a signed, first edition copy!

support.title: MAKE IT A DOUBLE!
support.descp: Order two signed copies of the hardcover edition - get one for yourself and send one to a saddle pal and as a bonus you will receive two signed, bookmarks, illustrated with a Joe DeYong sketch.

support.title: De Yong broadside & 2 signed books
support.descp: An 11” x 17” broadside features a De Yong pen and ink and poem – featured in the book - about one of Joe’s best friends – his rope! It’s a letterpress broadside pulled by master letterpress craftsman John Balkwill at Lumino Press in Santa Barbara. And this includes two signed De Yong book and bookmarks– also pulled by Mr. Balkwill.

support.title: Four Signed Books and Bookmarks
support.descp: Here's an easy way to pledge and reserve more books - get four signed books and bookmarks.

support.title: Eight Signed Books and Bookmarks
support.descp: Here's a way to get more books with a pledge or to adjust your existing pledge to include more copies. All are signed and include the letterpress bookmark.

support.title: SIGNED BOOK AND JOE BEELER PRINT
support.descp: In addition to a signed copy of the book and bookmark, this reward includes a signed print - from the book - by the late artist Joe Beeler (1931 - 2006) - a close friend of DeYong's. The print, titled "Shade" is one of five signed in the 1990s by - and in collaboration with - Joe Beeler (1931-2006).

support.title: Signed book and Jo Mora carte
support.descp: Joe De Yong enjoyed the authentic nature of artist Jo Mora's (1876 - 1947) work in his 1946 book "Trail Dust and Saddle Leather" and later in Mora's 1949,posthumously published "Californios." Both books influenced a number of the stories he would write and illustrate for Western Horseman magazine from 1948 - 1950. This special premium comes from Peter Hiller at the Jo Mora Trust and is an original 1945 version of Mora's carte of California (18 x 24). In addition, backer will receive a sign De Yong book and bookmark plus three rare books on Jo Mora: “Back to the Drawing Board” by Julianna Burton-Carvajal; “Joe Mora: Renaissance Man of the West” by Stephen Mitchell and “Collecting Jo Mora by Grandeau and Shorts. 1 available

support.title: Signed book and De Yong leather art
support.descp: In addition to a signed book and letterpress bookmark you'll receive an original piece of De Yong's "electric needle" art depicting a rider and reluctant mule. This piece is 10" x 27" long and is beautifully framed.

support.title: Signed book and Borein book
support.descp: This premium level includes a signed De Yong book and bookmark and a Fine Binding Edition Of ten etchings pulled from original Edward Borein plates authenticated by De Yong’s friend and Borein expert, the late Harold Davidson. This superbly custom bound, limited edition containing ten important etchings pulled from the original Borein plates including – Cinch Binder, Bronc Breaker, Scratchin' High, Bronco, Cutting Back Strays, Blackfoot Chiefs, Hopi Boys, The Wooden Bridge at Taos, and Mission San Antonio De Padua. Limited to a total of fifty twenty-five presentation editions, the volume bound in full English calf leather covers with richly gilt fronts and backs; spine finished with gold ornamentation and raised bands; top edge full gilt both inside front and back covers finished with gold dentelles. Each volume is housed in a slipcase with handmade marbled paper with top and bottom and finger pulls in fine leather. This book was created and published in 2002 by my father, John T. Reynolds, who passed away way too soon in 2008. There are only three available.

support.title: Signed Book and A.Harmer Watercolor
support.descp: In addition to a signed book and bookmark you will receive a watercolor of the California Mission San Luis Rey. Artist Alexander Harmer (1856-1925) was a friend of Joe De Yong’s in Santa Barbara. De Yong had been introduced to Harmer by Charles Lummis – a friend of Russell’s and Edward Borein’s. Harmer is considered the first painter of California’s vaquero culture and did a number of paintings of the California Missions. This watercolor of the Mission San Luis Rey is 6” x 14” and is matted and framed.

support.title: Signed Book plus Beeler book & sketch
support.descp: Joe Beeler was a dear friend of Joe’s and De Yong was a mentor to him as well as to artist Vel Miller. This premium is a first edition volume of Beeler’s 1967 book “Cowboys and Indians” and comes along with signed and framed sketch by Beeler drawn on Montana’s OW Ranch in the 1990s. There is only one of this premium and of course it comes with a signed De Yong book and bookmark.

support.title: Signed Book and photo of Bill Hart
support.descp: Silent screen cowboy star, William S. Hart was a close friend of De Yong's during and after Charlie Russell's death. In addition to your signed copy and book mark comes a framed, signed silver print of William S. Hart along with an additional signature.

support.title: SIGNED BOOK & DeYONG WATERCOLOR
support.descp: After you have finished the signed copy of the book you received, you can concentrate on hanging an original costume sketch by Joe DeYong as illustrated in the book. And of course you can mark the page with your signed-by-the-author book mark.

support.title: Signed Book and A. Harmer gouache
support.descp:
This is the largest premium and hopefully a savvy collector will see the crazy-good value here. Alexander Harmer (1866 – 1925) was De Yong’s friend – and for a while his landlord as De Yong rented studio space from him. Harmer painted this gouache illustration for the 1914 book by Jarrett Richards, “Romance on El Camino Real.” Harmer illustrated the book with 13 gouaches and this one appears on page 15 – and yes along with your signed De Yong book and bookmark – you’ll received the framed painting and a first edition copy of Richards’ book. There is only 1 of this premium.
It will be on my Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/bill.reynolds.756
for viewing as are all the premiums.

updates.update_userinfo: Remembering Mary "Banty" De Yong on Mother's Day
The sound of ink hitting paper
updates.update_content: We are now, dear backers, in that Twilight Zone area of waiting. All approvals at the printer have been accomplished and we are now knee deep in production. The whickety, whickety, whack of the printing presses are rolling on. It appears that if all goes well - and it should - the books will leave Michigan on their way to Santa Ynez around May 14. Probably about a week we figure to get here. We will be shipping to all of you first, of course, and will start no later than the first week of June. Your support has made this happen and I thank you again for your kindness.

I am pleased to tell everyone that the De Yong book is at the printer going through "pre-flight checking" making sure all the files are correct. This is what takes place before ink starts hitting paper - one of my favorite things! Robin Ireland and I have spent the past 30 days proofing and reproofing. I will have the expected delivery date for you in about a week so stay tuned as we go on this ride together. Thank you as always for your support of this project.
Bill

updates.update_userinfo: Joe De Yong Book Update - end of March
updates.update_content: My dearest Backers, recently I sent you a survey via Kickstarter for you to provide your mail and delivery address along with contact information. Books will be sent via USPS with some of the larger premium items shipping via FedEx or UPS. Most of you have responded and I give you my thanks. If you have not, please do so that when we are ready to ship - we can, quickly. The files will be shipped to the printer around April 6-ish. It will take 30 - 35 days to print and then a week or so to ship them to me. I am very pleased to be printing the book in the United States by a printer who started with one magazine in 1915 in Pennsylvania. They do wonderful work and I think you will be pleased with the quality of the presentation. Art director/designer Robin Ireland who designed and has done a superb job.

updates.update_userinfo: Joe De Yong Backer Surveys have been sent.
updates.update_content: Good morning Joe De Yong Project supporters. I have sent out Backer Surveys to each of you based on your Backer level. The survey asks for your shipping address and contact information so I can get your books and goodies to you once we are ready to ship in June. You will note that phone numbers and email addresses are asked for so please make sure you provide those so I can communicate with you beyond these Updates - which I will continue to send you as we go through the process. Please feel free to email me directly with any questions at wcreynolds@mac.com.

To all my wonderful supporters, thank you. The book will know be printed and out there. It has been a large part of my life for many years - frankly since I met De Yong in 1962.
You will be receiving some information from me shortly regarding your backing level and questions about shipping addresses so get ready. But above all, thanks to all of you for helping me celebrate the legacy of Joe De Yong.
Bill

Good morning and happy Monday, we have literally 24 hours left in the Joe De Yong campaign. If you have anyone you can think of who can jump on Joe's train before tomorrow morning, please invite them to participate. I will be contacting you all after the active Kickstarter part of the event closes tomorrow in order to get information regarding shipment once the book is printed. You have all been glorious to support this effort and it is succeeding beyond my dreams. Thank you, Bill

Dear beloved backers, we a rounding the clubhouse turn for the De Yong campaign and you all have been wonderfully supportive. Many of you have registered as guests and once the campaign closes Tuesday morning, I will be sending all what Kickstarter calls Backer Surveys, based on your pledge level. These enable me to get your shipping address and other contact information so that when we start sending things out in early June, we have everything we need. If you did register as a guest, please feel free to drop me an email to wcreynolds@mac.com and jump start the process by giving me shipping address, etc. We will be using USPS for book shipments and UPS or FedEx for those who will receive artwork so take note of that for shipping addresses.

campaign.story:
Hi! Thanks for taking a look at my project. As you can see, I'd love to publish a brand-new book of paintings of my home town, Bath. 
This will be my second book about the city. I published 'Brown's Bath' in 2008, and I'm down to my last couple of boxes. Rather than reprint, I decided it better to start from scratch (my work's moved on in ten years) and create a brand-new hardback gift book, to match the format and design of my recent London book.
I've been capturing the city for twenty years now, always painting from life in all weathers, so I've built up quite a selection of images to choose from.
The book will feature 130+ paintings and drawings, as well as stories and annecdotes 'from the street'. I hope Bath's residents and visitors will enjoy this celebration of the city, as well as fellow artists and art lovers.
My London book started life as a Kickstarter project, so I'm turning again to you - my crowdfunding chums - to help me make this happen. The team that produced the London book are poised to work their magic on this project, but there are not-unsubstantial upfront costs associated with printing a high-quality colour hardback gift book, so I'm hoping you'll be able to lend me your support in return for one of the following rewards...
Rewards
As well as the book itself, I've got a whole host of other goodies for you to choose from including limited edition prints, original oil paintings and the chance to spend a day painting with me. Or, if you're feeling really altruistic, you can make a small pledge in return for nothing more than my gratitude. If you want a combination or permutation of rewards items that's not covered by the packages listed, drop me a message and we'll figure something out.
The book
Bath: Paintings by Peter Brown. 156 pages crammed with 130+ paintings and drawings, along with accompanying annecdotes to give you additional context and insight. Kickstarter price: £25 (RRP will be £30 upon publication).
 2019 wall calendar. A painting of Bath for every month. A great Christmas gift, or stick it on your very-own fridge door.
London: Paintings by Peter Brown - the fruits of my first Kickstarter project. Same format as my new Bath book, so a companion volume for anyone out there who hasn't already got a copy!
Book Bundle
Contains all of the above PLUS 'Brown's Bath' (my 2008 Bath book); 'My Indian Travels' and a book of London painting postcards.
Limited Edition Print (1 of 50)
A rare opportunity to own a signed, numbered, limited edition. 18" x 24" giclée print of the cover artwork for the book. I generally don't really sell prints - you could say my prints are rarer than my originals! Here are the specs from the printer, for those who understand them: Cannon 4000 Pro printer, on Hahnemühle Photo Rag Ultra Smooth 100% Cotton Rag, pH neutral, acid-free art paper. 12-colour Lucia Pro ink which is colour fast for 80+ years.
You can choose to receive the print and my new Bath book; or the print and book bundle, which works out as great value.
Paint with Pete The Street (that's me!)
Another rare opportunity: I offered this as a reward on my London book Kickstarter, and was delighted that people actually wanted to hang out with me for a day's painting! This time I'm offering two outings: one in Bath [SORRY! ALL BATH SPACES BOOKED!] and one by the coast (probably Devon or Dorset) with up to 5 spaces available on each day, so you'll get to meet other plein air enthusiasts too. (lunch provided; travel and expenses not included; date to be arranged to suit all participants; all abilities welcome.) We had great fun last time, so don't be shy!
Original oil paintings
"Beckford’s Tower, Snow, 2018" 
Oil on board, framed, 12" x 10" - a new one, painted earlier this year. Price tag would normally be £2,700, but I'll let it go here for £1,950. I'll even throw in a copy of my new Bath book; can't say fairer than that!
"Over Pulteney Bridge, the Day Grayson Perry Came to Town" *SORRY, THIS HAS NOW BEEN SNAPPED-UP!*
That's all folks!
Thanks for reading this far. I hope there's something to tickle your fancy in amongst the selection of rewards. Do drop me a message if there's a combination of individual items that's not listed; or if you have any other questions.
All that's left to say is THANK YOU for your interest and support!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As with any publishing project there are risks and challenges, but I'm feeling quietly confident as I have several published books, including 'London: Paintings by Peter Brown' which started life here on Kickstarter, so I understand the process. I'll be using the same team for editorial, design, marketing, sales, etc so everything should run like clockwork (touch wood and all that...)

I plan on partnering with Sansom & Co, an established independent art publisher - who were also on board for my London book - on the print/production side to ensure a high-quality finished product.

There's no shortage of paintings for me to choose from for inclusion! The challenge will be choosing the best selection for the book, but I've already started thinking about this and am looking forward to revisiting scenes from the past, as well as more recent works. And I need to write some interesting words . . .

We've got a schedule drawn-up, ready to start as soon as the Kickstarter ends. Lots to do, but very-much achievable. Our aim is to have the books ready by October 2018, i.e. in good time for Christmas.

Can't wait!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
The Frozen Latitudes Expeditions
Mockup of the book's beautiful cover and back page.
Have you ever had the feeling of being alone, completely exposed to the nowhere under bitterly cold conditions? I did! In several expeditions with a small group of friends over nearly 30 years we were literally cut-off from the civilization for several weeks. There was no telecommunication, no infrastructure, no contact to anyone. Just us and the forces of the Arctic nature. Every step created a lasting impact on the ground, followed by a clear, crunchy noise as our feet compressed various layers of snow. The strong wind in our faces caused pain and one crew member froze his feet and couldn’t feel them for several months. But we had to go on. By ranging deeper and deeper into the remote land we got so much rewarded by the real beauty of Frozen Latitudes. The experiences we made and the shifts in our minds were worth all the frost bites and in the end we were completely fused with the nature and everything was just good. We could not have experienced such a freedom without complete dedication to the very moment at the very places we were.
The remoteness of Arctic landscape lets the tiny person dissappear in the vastness of the snow covered mountains. What is man in the vastness of Frozen Latitudes? A breathing heartbeat.
"Our internal goal, which guided the external goal of looking for possible routes, was strongly influenced by the yearning for pristine landscapes, untouched by humans. The harsh beauty of the Arctic landscape, with its barren nature, should resonate at a deeper level and even touch our souls. Actually, we were looking for the permanent in the changing forms or for the eternal in the transient. Contemplating the landscape which is being shaped by ice through the enormous forces of cryogenesis, virtual Frozen Morphs emerged - visions of the morphology of frozen landscapes - which became a reality through our experiences. Comparable to the desert experiences of the ancient Christian hermits hundreds of years ago, our image of Frozen Latitudes was complemented by a spiritual dimension: how is each of us going to deal with loneliness and absolute self-reliance?”
Excerpt from the book's passionate stories.
The omnipresent fog covers Cape Flora Island, Franz Josef Land
The Fine Art Photo Book
My limited edition fine arts photo book Frozen Latitudes will give a portrait of the beauty of the High Arctic. It is my photographic tribute to the Arctic cryosphere which is currently undergoing a fundamental change by becoming un-frozen. Still, it is dominated by the processes of cryogenesis: the creation of landscapes from the freezing and thawing of earth’s materials. The book's mission is also a call for more humility and a plea for us all to pay attention to the cryosphere and the importance of it being preserved for future generations.
Nature shapes icebergs incredibly beautiful, Franz Josef Land.
Frozen Latitudes will be an extraordinary book of 288 pages with about 320 photos and maps presenting rare panoramic views portraying some of the remotest landscapes of the High Arctic in Greenland and far up to Franz Josef Land and the Arctic Ocean. They are solely formed by natural forces such as wind, water and ice and are perceived as existing since the very early times of the Earth's Genesis. Animals and artifacts often appear unexpectedly in these landscapes and set accents that emphasize the vastness of the nature with its inherent impression of permanence. In search of Pure Landscapes it is my photographic challenge to capture the everlasting natural changes which are hard to recognize by human scales.
Kirken - the Sagrada Familia of Northeast Greenland.
Six text chapters will present essays about my experiences when ranging through the High Arctic and are supplemented by the scientific perspectives of the cryosphere and how it is affected by the observed trends of global warming, written by Professor Dr. Wolfgang Schöner - the internationally renown Austrian glaciologist and secretary of the Austrian Polar Research Institute APRI.
The publication of the book is scheduled for June 2018. It will be published bilingual in English and German by the German publishing company Seltmann und Söhne specialized in fine arts photo books - if I can raise the money for the print production expenses. For that I ask for your valuable help. Get inspired by the preview of the book below.
The Mission
I ask for your generous support for my book project - you will be rewarded with extraordinary photos and ambitious stories full of passion for the High Arctic. Its remarkable design and layout will be produced by one of Germany's best photo book publishing companies. Any support is appreciated ranging from the beautiful post cards over early bird book bargains to personally signed books. You can even join me on the special Frozen Latitudes expedition to Spitsbergen and receive your personal book copy right in the High Arctic. Or you participate at the book unboxing event at my home in the heart of the Wienerwald, Austria. Decorate your home or event locations with one of the incredibly beautiful canvas prints with optionally handmade color finish from one of the book’s photos.
So please do not hesitate and become an enthusiastic backer, go for one of the attractive pledges and help spreading the word. Thank You!
The Preview
Mockup of the book's beautiful cover and back page.
  The book will be divided into six chapters.
  Each chapter tells a story in English and German about my experiences when ranging through Frozen Latitudes.
  The impact of climate change on the cryosphere by Professor Dr. Wolfgang Schöner, Austrian Polar Research Institute APRI.
  Aurora Borealis at its best!
  Read about a winter dog sledge skiing expedition with Inuits from Northeast Greenland.
    Polar bears on Franz Josef Land in search for food. They are actually sea mammals and not adopted to an ice free Ocean.
  Large ice caps cover the islands of Franz Josef Land. Enjoy rare panormamic views from some of the remotest places on earth.
  Walrus eyes are red with a billion years old glimpse of the Earth's Genesis.
  One of the remotest settlements on earth is Ittoqqortoormiit located in Northeast Greenland with about 400 inhabitants - 800 km away from the next village, over wild and glaciated mountain ranges.
  Panoramic canvas print as living room decoration.
  My canvas prints decorating the antique event halls of the Austrian Academy of Sciencies, Vienna.
  Canvas print of Wiener Neustadt Island outlet glacier (120 x 80 cm)
  Canvas print "The storm wanderer", cemetry of Ittoqqortoormiit, 30 x 20 cm.
  Canvas print of Salisbury Island's glacier reflections (200 x 80 cm).
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The Arctic can be a risky and challenging place, and apart from minor frost bites I'm thankful that so far I've come through relatively unscathed! Creating "Frozen Latitudes" might seem straightforward in comparison, but it is difficult to do well in order to have a fully pleasing and high quality photo book. There are almost no risks involved at this stage with the printing of this book. All the photo development, story writing and layout work of the last months is behind me. A noted publisher was found to match the high quality photo print requirements who is fully engaged to make the book a success. The final challenge is to ensure that this Kickstarter campaign succeeds in order to cover the print production costs, so that I can trigger the book’s production for the Spring 2018 program.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Dear Supporters and Friends,
A year ago you decided to support my fine art book project FROZEN LATITUDE. Thank you so much to make it happening.

updates.update_userinfo: Unwrapping of Frozen Latitudes - Auspacken von Frozen Latitudes
updates.update_content:
Sitting on the grass roof of our shed and enjoying a Wienerwald Spring morning
(-> Deutscher Text unten)
I could see a parcel delivery van turning into our side road and stopping in front of our house. On the parcel I spotted the letters "Seltmann PrintArt" and knew it was the delivery of the first two copies of Frozen Latitudes. I heard my heart beat going up and felt joy flowing through my body. I got up from the grass roof and climbed down the ladder to receive the parcel from the postman. I climbed back onto the roof to unwrap Frozen Latitudes in quietness and with caution. I placed the parcel on the tundra-like low vegetation of the roof and looked at the parcel to enjoy it from outside. I unwrapped the book and was so pleased about the result and the achieved quality of the manufacturing process. I felt gratitude to all who had helped and taken responsibility to produce Frozen Latitudes. I touched the cover and felt the texture of the fly leave colored in the Frozen Latitudes blue. I browsed through the book and realized that Frozen Latitudes have become real, also because of the book's 2 kg weight lasting on my knees. I climbed down from the roof to touch solid ground. Now it was there!

Although we are still below the goal I was hoping to reach in order to fully cover the production costs I'm very happy about what we have reached. One shall never be disappointed about respectable achievements as one's Ego is never satisfied.

updates.update_userinfo: Back from Siberia: We reached the campaign goal!
updates.update_content:
Dear Supporters of Frozen Latitudes,
I just returned safely from Lake Baikal in Siberia with a wealth of incredible experiences from a land where winter is just as normal as eating your daily bread. We had temperatures between -10 and -30 Celsius and walked in total 70 km on the totally frozen lake and up into the surrounding hills to spot it from above. An evening without Banya (Sauna) would not have followed the typical Siberian way of life - and a jump through a freshly opened ice hole into the lake was the topping of a good day.

Dear friends of "Frozen Latitudes",
the funding goal has almost been reached - wow, thank you all so much for your support until now!
For the new backers on board, I am right now on an expedition at Lake Baikal, Russia. I want to share an update with you:

campaign.story:
For the first time in hundreds of years,
artist George Cochrane brings us a manuscript edition of Dante's masterpiece. We are excited to bring together this iconic text and the craftsmanship of the Medieval scribe and bookmaker. Allow us to introduce INFERNO.
Learn more about Dante's Inferno in this interview . . . 
This edition is unlike any you've ever seen. Not only is it printed letterpress and hand-bound, but each letter of each line has been written by hand, and each margin is lush with illustration.
In bringing together Dante and George Cochrane, each masters of their own craft, we hope to bring forward an edition of INFERNO unlike any which has ever existed. It is a manuscript edition (hand-lettered, hand-illustrated) which Dante would have found familiar, brought to life by the finest letterpress printing and hand binding. 
Allow us to introduce you to INFERNO, a letterpress printed and hand-bound book . . . 
We are proud to present 'Inferno'—in four magnificent versions.
Each binding offers something unique - check out the 'THREE BINDINGS' tier to get a copy of each!
A handmade book, through and through.
George has spent years hand-lettering this edition. The text is presented in both Italian and in English, and each margin illustrates the scene on the page. As he says, the lush illustrations give the reader a "visual gloss" as they follow Dante down into the depths. 
Each page was drawn completely by hand . . .
. . . with Dante's poetry hand-lettered, and marginal illustrations bringing each scene to life.
What is a 'fine press' book?
While most books are commercially mass-produced by machine, these are not. They are made by hand. When you add a Thornwillow fine press book to your collection, you can expect:
Each page to be printed letterpress. You can feel the impression of the type as you run your finger across the page.
Each book to be expertly hand-bound, using only the finest materials. 
Each book to be individually hand numbered.
And finally, when you pledge, your name is included on a subscribers list accompanying every book, and archived in the world's greatest collections.
Please enjoy this short film by our friends at Surrender Pictures about the Thornwillow philosophy   .   .   .
PLAY

What's different about this edition?
Friends of Thornwillow—those who have been collecting for years or who have just started—should know a few, exciting things which differentiate this edition from our past ones.
It is printed in two colors, in both red and black.
It is larger. While The Shakespeare Sonnets, Sherlock Holmes Hexalogy, Three War Stories, and Frankenstein were all roughly quarto size, this is printed in a folio format. (See the photos below for a comparison.)
The book has no typesetting—everything from the magnificent illustrations to the copyright page is in George's own hand.
INFERNO is the fifth edition we've brought to life with crowdfunding. We are offering two of the previous editions, THE SHAKESPEARE SONNETS and SHERLOCK HOLMES HEXALOGY alongside it.
PAPER-WRAPPER | $85. Edition size limited to one hundred more than backed.
Our paper-wrapper version is bound in a letterpress cover.
CLOTH | $185. Edition size limited to one hundred more than backed.
Our half-cloth version is bound in scarlet book cloth and letterpress board papers. The text is printed letterpress on heavy felt paper, with letterpress patterned endpapers.
HALF-LEATHER | Starting at $585. Only 66 copies available.
Our half-leather version is bound in scarlet Moroccan goatskin with handmade pastepaper. It comes in a suede-lined clamshell box with a leather spine label.
FULL-LEATHER | Starting at $1,500. Six versions available.
The Inferno centers on Dante, Virgil, and Beatrice. We are offering six copies of each in Full-Leather with their motifs gold tooled into the cover. Dante is bound in scarlet Morocco. Virgil is bound in Edwardian brown Morocco. Beatrice is bound in terracotta Morocco. 
Most spectacularly of all, we are offering three unique copies. When Dante reaches the bottom of Inferno, he finds the Devil three headed. The left head is black, the middle head is crimson, and the right head is yellow. Together, they are devouring Brutus, Cassius, and Judas Iscariot. We have crafted three monumental copies, representing the three heads, each set with gems in their eyes.
Moreover, each of these one-of-a-kind copies is printed on its own special paper stock and comes with an actual manuscript leaf by George Cochrane.
Most magnificently of all, the Middle Devil copy is also copiously hand-colored and extra illustrated by the artist. 
The Full-Leather bindings.
Each individual book is hand-bound at the press. Our master binders use the highest quality archival paper stock, book cloth and vegetable tanned Moroccan goatskin.
CLOTH and HALF-LEATHER copies are bound with Fleur-de-lis letterpress endpapers.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Having conducted twenty projects in the past, each of which has been delivered on time, we are confident in our ability to successfully manage any unexpected challenges. That said, we will always communicate them to our backers if they do arise.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: We have a parable to sow...
updates.update_content:
As backers of the Thornwillow edition of Dante's Inferno, I wanted to make sure you are aware of our newest campaign, currently live (and thriving!) on Kickstarter.
For the first time ever in a fine press edition, we are proud to present:
Parable of the Sower by Octavia Butler.

updates.update_userinfo: Avoid the circles of Hell... be part of a broadside revolution...
updates.update_content:
Dear Friends of Thornwillow
On the eve of a presidential election and in the midst of an unprecedented pandemic, we have decided to deploy our resources as a printer and publisher of handmade limited editions to unite our communities in support of civic participation and to call out for change. Thornwillow is proud to present:
Declaration: Signs of Change

updates.update_content: Announcing Agatha Christie's DEATH ON THE NILE from Thornwillow Press

updates.update_userinfo: A new book with Henry Louis Gates Jr.
updates.update_content:
Dear friends,
On Tuesday, we launched our newest book in partnership with renowned historian Henry Louis Gates Jr — it's called Frederick Douglass: Portrait of a Free Man. It tells the story of one of the most important figures in American history who, now more than ever, is a shining example of how one can better society during troubled times.

Dear friends,
We are excited to announce the launch of our newest publication, THE GREAT GATSBY. We have been so honored by all of the wonderful feedback we have received from you on INFERNO, and we wanted you to be among the first to know about this new edition.
Take me to the Jazz Age!

updates.update_userinfo: ANNOUNCING: Beauty is the Beginning of Terror
updates.update_content:
Dear friends, 
We are so pleased to announce our next book: Beauty is the Beginning of Terror.
This week marks the centennial of the end of the First World War. In remembrance of this international event, we have worked with the cadets and faculty of the U. S. Military Academy at West Point to put together an anthology of writings from The Great War unlike any which has ever existed. The book boasts twelve never-before-seen facsimile reproductions of artifacts from the War, and the introduction is written by General Martin E. Dempsey, who served as the highest U. S. military official, as President Obama's Chairman of the Joint Chiefs.

Friends,
Nearly every half-leather copy is out the door!  The feedback we've been receiving has been overwhelming.  THANK YOU.  Half-cloth copies have begun shipping; the bindery has been in full swing; half-cloth subscribers should be expecting their tracking codes soon.  
As you may have seen, yesterday we launched our next title—Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice!  Many of you have subscribed already, and have, again, impressed the publishing world with your commitment to fine ideas in fine books. Again, thank you.

campaign.story:
Voyage is a bi-annual travel magazine crafted by undergraduate students at the University of Washington. 
With stories and photos that span from our home turf, the Pacific Northwest, and across the world, we seek to inspire adventure and increase cultural and geographic awareness. 
Our 4th issue, the Perspective Issue, strives to highlight individuals whose stories have been historically neglected and continue to go largely unpublished. We hope this issue of Voyage offers new perspectives on travel and captures the importance of representation.
  On February 21st at 7 pm, we will be hosting a free screening of An American Ascent, a documentary that follows the first all African American climbing expedition to summit Denali. A Q&A session will follows afterwards with Adina Scott and Rosemary Saal, two incredible hikers who will tell us more about the importance of representation and women leadership in the outdoors!
RSVP your seat
    Voyage Merchandise
Voyage Patch
  Stickers (don't mind the pricing)
Our Team
Our team has grown over the past two years and we've been joined by some new faces. We all boast distinct skills from programming to financial management, but we have all found solace and excitement in exploring the world. Putting our forces together, we’ve curated a magazine that focuses on those converging interests.
Learn more about our individual team members.
Our Community
Like all past issues, this one also couldn't have happened without your ongoing support. Our past photography panels, hikes, and launch parties have gathered a community of amazing artists, travelers, and adventurers who are always ready for more! 
Cool things we've done: 
Published in Elliot Bay Bookstore, Bulldog News, and UW Bookstore
Hosted photo panels with prominent photographers Scott Kranz and Andrew Kearns
Partnered with BlackRapid, Evo, SIFF, and other local companies 
Held 2 photography competitions for the UW community with over 200 submissions
To everyone who has supported us this far, we are so grateful; to those who have shared your stories and trusted us with a piece of your heart, we thank you.   
_____________
Website
Instagram // @Voyage_UW // #VoyageUW
Facebook
A big thank you to Wells Fargo and the UW Alumni Association for sponsoring our issue.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Thank you for your interest in Voyage's 4th issue. As with all productions on Kickstarter, there are certain risks and challenges to be addressed should you decide to contribute to our project. 

1. Changes in supplier: For this issue, we have decided to partner with a new supplier, Girlie Press. Girlie Press is a seasoned veteran in the printing industry and have been specializing in print for a long time. We are excited to work with them and strive to ensure quality magazines be produced for our contributors.

2. Delays in shipment: Voyage continues our usual on-campus distribution. In addition, we also constantly strive to push out shipments and mailings in an orderly and timely fashion. However, we do apologize for any delay in shipments. The Voyage team would be in contact upon project completion to ensure a smooth process.

We look forward to having the magazine out for everyone. Do reach out should there be any concerns.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Our 8th issue, the Home Issue, is LIVE!
updates.update_content:
Thank you so much for ordering the Perspective Issue! We sincerely hope you enjoyed it as much as we did. If you have any feedbacks, feel free to send it our way! If you have not received the issue, please reach out to us so we can troubleshoot what when wrong together!
Secondly, our latest issue, the Home Issue, is currently live on Kickstarter! Through this issue, we hope to reexamine the role of travel in our lives as the world faces the unprecedented challenge of COVID-19. More specifically, we have been confronted with the concept of home: How do we define home? Can our concept of home reach beyond a physical location? How can our perception of home evolve and grow? From East Asia to the Olympic Peninsula, our writers, photographers, and artists tell stories of growing up, connecting with their heritage, and finding a section of the earth they call home. Support our latest issue by preordering on Kickstarter and find out how much we have grown as a team! Check out our if you are interested in purchasing a past issue!

updates.update_userinfo: THE FOOD ISSUE HAS BEEN LAUNCHED
updates.update_content:
Thank you for all of your support to our previous Perspective Issue. 
We have just released our 5th issue "The Food Issue", celebrating the universal love language of food and the lessons we learned from eating our way around the globe. The latest copy is by far our best issue ever been produced in terms of quality. 48 pages of beautiful photos, illustrations, and stories. This issue is not only aesthetically pleasing as a quality magazine, but also fun, vibrant, authentic, full of energy, and personal.

Hi everyone,
As issue 4 winds down, I would like to once again take the opportunity to thank everyone.
We have shipped out all the packages successfully and you should be receiving them anytime now. If you are picking up from campus, we have sent an email detailing instructions for further steps. Collection begins next week.

Did you know that Voyage was founded less than 2 years ago?
But, after 4 issues, many events and countless of hours working on making the magazine possible, we are very proud of how far we have come. I will always remember the days when our events were small and intimate, and now,  look forward to those that bring together people from all walks of lives.

WE ARE 100% FUNDED!
Thank you to each and every one of you for making this happen! We have less than 48 hours remaining and the team and I can't wait to get our magazine to you.
Upon project completion, we will be rolling out a backer survey to gather more information. This survey would ask you for your preferred method of delivery, address, email, etc. Everything we need to get your reward to you! After which, we would begin delivery on a rolling basis. We will, of course, keep you in the loop.

We are a little more than half way to our goal! Thank you all for the  support. We cannot wait to get our magazine to you.
In the meantime, we are having our launch event this Friday 02/09 at MiiR Flagship at Fremont, WA. You can RSVP on our FB event AND Eventbrite.
In addition, in conjunction with Black History Month, we are screening An American Ascent on 2/21 at the Ethnic Cultural Center. An American Ascent is a film following the first all African American team to summit Denali. It is a fantastic film addressing under-represented communities in the outdoors. We are also very happy to have Rosemary Saal and Adina Scott, two members of the team, join us for the screening. Admission is free! Do RSVP !

Hi backers,
We noticed that we did not previously create an option for on-campus pick up. However, we have just added two additional rewards that does so. If you choose to back our project, be sure to select the right one.
If you had already backed our project and want an on-campus pick up, we can provide a refund of the shipping cost upon pick up.

campaign.story:
Working design of the Contents page.
 About Backstage at The Lost Colony
For eight decades, The Lost Colony has defied the odds. From its improbable founding during the Great Depression, through flood and fires, playwright Paul Green’s first and most famous symphonic outdoor drama is a study in resilience. And like the "lost" colonists of Roanoke Island, the people who created and sustained The Lost Colony—and who continue to preserve its legacy—are a study in passion and determination.
Much has been written about The Lost Colony and the historical event that inspired it, but Backstage at The Lost Colony is the first book to go behind the scenes to offer a view of the show the audience never sees—the grinding toil, the artistic vision, the occasional mishaps, the moments of mischief and glimpses of grace.
  Photo by Delena Gray Ostrander
  Photo by Delena Gray Ostrander
    Photo by Jamil Zraikat
  In Backstage at The Lost Colony, author Dwayne Walls follows the cast and crew through The Lost Colony’s 80th production season. His observations are supplemented by first-person stories from Colony alumni and about 100 photos, mostly color, by photographers such as Delena Gray Ostrander, Eden Saunders, Duane Cochran, and Jamil Zraikat.
This is not an historical account of the show, though it does discuss the drama's founding, important milestones, and near-death experiences. Rather, we wanted to offer readers a fresh look at a legend in American theater, because, while we honor the past, we hope to illustrate that The Lost Colony, with its themes of freedom, community, hope, and optimism, is as relevant today as it was in 1937 when it premiered to a standing-room-only audience of more than 2,000 people. 
Our fondest wish is that you will support our passion project AND take in a performance of The Lost Colony during its 81st season. 
  The manuscript is final and we're in design and production, on schedule to publish in May.
  Author Dwayne Walls follows the cast and crew through the 80th production season.
  The narrative is supplemented with first-person stories from alumni, who share some of their favorite memories.
About the Author
Photo of Dwayne Walls Jr. by Frederick V. Nielsen II
The son of a journalist, Dwayne Walls Jr. is uniquely suited to tell the Backstage story. He first signed on with The Lost Colony as a 19 year-old actor technician—a hapless “space puppy” who was too preoccupied with the itch of his colonist’s beard and the paucity of his paycheck to enjoy his first summer with the show. But he returned a few years later with a different outlook and, even though his beard still itched, he grew both professionally and personally. Through his experience with The Lost Colony, Dwayne developed an enduring appreciation for the work and the workers behind the scenes, which is evident in the story he tells.
After leaving The Lost Colony, Dwayne went on to New York City to build sets for theater, film, and television—including NBC’s Saturday Night Live. These days, he lives with his wife Elizabeth in Pittsboro, North Carolina, where he remains a member in good standing of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees Local One.
How We'll Use the Funds
The book will be printed in a quality full-color paperback format (dimensions about 8" x 9") and will be 160 to 176 pages (as this campaign begins, we're just heading into design and production). We set an ambitious goal of $15,000 to offset the costs of design, production, and printing. That's only part of the cost of publishing this book, and here's how the estimates break down:
Pre-press: $7,500.00
 Printers Proofs $1,000.00 
 Printing/shipping $7,200.00 
TOTAL: $15,700
 This doesn't include costs such as the author's royalties, marketing, developmental editing, and distribution. If we exceed our goal, we'll use the extra funds to add photography and increase the print run.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have been working on this book since early 2016, when we first posted a Facebook page announcing our intention to the Lost Colony community, which showed enthusiastic support right from the beginning (thank you!). We brought author Dwayne Walls on board just prior to the start of the 80th season, and he delivered a 37,000-word-plus manuscript several weeks thereafter. After editing and photo selection, the final manuscript went into design and production in January. We'll finalize cover and interior designs while this campaign is in progress, and the files will go to the printer in March. Printing bids are in hand, and we have chosen a printer in the United States. We're on schedule to have copies in hand for The Lost Colony's 2018 Opening Night (May 25). We are far enough along in the process to feel confident in our schedule.

To ensure a top quality book, we put together a top-notch team: 

--Julie Allred of BW&A Books of Oxford, N.C. (bwabooks.com), who is handling design, production, and printing coordination

--Stephen Kirk, who has edited such titles as Voices from the Outer Banks and First in Flight: The Wright Brothers in North Carolina

--Elizabeth Evans, a public relations strategist and former PR director for The Lost Colony

--Christina Sherlock, who brings her experience from Fortune 500 operational excellence roles to advise us on this book
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
