updates.update_userinfo: An important notice about our first Kickstarter campaign
updates.update_content:
To everyone who pledged to our earlier (cancelled) campaign at levels that include being listed in the book--if you haven't already supported the new campaign, we want to make sure you're aware that the deadline is fast approaching on some reward tiers.
We are going to print soon, so we're on a tight deadline to complete the list of backers who want to be recognized in the book. Those rewards will no longer be available after February 27.

updates.update_userinfo: Time is running out to be listed in the hardcover limited edition
updates.update_content:
We have relaunched advance book sales through a new Kickstarter campaign. You can view it here: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1250572141/backstage-at-the-lost-colony-limited-edition-hardc 
After input from backers and our followers on Facebook, we are using the campaign to print a hardcover limited edition--a true "coffee table" book. We have also increased the number of pages (176) and added to the number of photos (more than 100).

updates.update_userinfo: Five days left to be a 'Keeper of the Dream'!
updates.update_content:
As announced yesterday to our backers, it is clear that we will not reach the ambitious goal we set for our Kickstarter campaign, so we are cancelling this campaign and will relaunch on Tuesday, Feb. 20.
We have learned a lot from this campaign and the tremendous feedback we've received from backers and our followers on social media. We're grateful for the feedback, which comes at a time in the production schedule when we can make revisions to the design and format and still make our publication deadline of late May 2018.

updates.update_userinfo: Relaunched Kickstarter campaign for hardcover limited edition!
updates.update_content:
To Our Wonderful Supporters:
Thanks to the efforts of PR genius Elizabeth Evans, we have our first media interviews scheduled. We'll be talking about the book tomorrow, Feb. 6, at about 11:15 with John Harper on 99.1 The Sound and Thursday, Feb. 8, (time TBD) with Mike Smith on Beach 104. We're excited to spread the news!
We're well into design for the interior of the book, and I'll post some of the work-in-progress here for you to see toward the end of the week. We'll turn our attention to cover designs the following week.

campaign.story:
We hit our goal and are still going...this time to make Nowhere and your Print Annuals even better.
If we make...
$25k: We're adding a travel pocket to the back of every Print Annual, for keepsakes, tickets, notes and other bric-a-brac.
$28k: We are going to (finally) make e-book versions of every Print Annual we've ever made, for those who love to read on a screen.
$30k: Will finance an entirely new section on the website dedicated to travel writing of yore. Hand-picked stories and essays from the greatest travel writers of the last century and beyond.    
Pledge $40 or more and get your name on the Acknowledgments page of the 10th Anniversary Print Annual.
We started Nowhere 10 years ago! (With $50 and a domain name.) We were tired of reading—and writing—brochure-esque, marketing-driven travel stories that have taken over much of the travel media world. We wanted to bring back old school, immersive, longform travel writing like Holiday, Colliers and the Saturday Evening Post used to run. Jack Kerouac was a travel writer back then. Arthur Miller was a travel writer. Hemingway, Faulkner, Jan Morris, Steinbeck and Mary McCarthy were travel writers.
Jack Kerouac was a travel writer back then. Arthur Miller was a travel writer. Hemingway, Faulkner, Jan Morris, Steinbeck and Mary McCarthy were travel writers.
We wanted stories that didn't just tell you where to stay and what to do in a place, but made you feel, smell, taste and hear it. We launched the magazine online so we could instantly publish it in every country in the world. Ten years and 500 travel features later, we publish to a readership of 20,000 across 119 countries.
We have seen dozens of travel magazines come and go since we started. They were all great, but most fell prey to the ambition to grow, monetize, merge, get bought, buy-out, get famous... Nowhere never strived to get bigger. We just wanted to get better.
And we did. One hundred percent of our content now comes from submissions. We receive thousands of stories every year and sift through them slowly and thoughtfully. The stories the editors select go through a complete editing and design process, followed by promotion and, for the best work, submission to national competitions and awards. We have won Lowell Thomas Travel Journalism Awards and been anthologized in Best American Travel Writing. The Review Review wrote, "Nowhere’s pages are full of the kind of stories mainstream travel magazines insert as an afterthought, a brief and rare glimpse into the traveler’s inner journey reflected through the exterior trip.” 
The Review Review wrote, "Nowhere’s pages are full of the kind of stories mainstream travel magazines insert as an afterthought, a brief and rare glimpse into the traveler’s inner journey reflected through the exterior trip.”
All of that takes a tremendous amount of time and a surprising amount of money. We now have a managing editor to answer emails, manage submissions, keep the website running and get our stories out to the world. We are planning a series of guidebooks and another series of travel books. 
We launch a Kickstarter campaign every year to pay for all of this, bring in a new crop of readers and writers, check in with our loyal supporters and shout out to the world that in the most challenging climate the publishing industry has ever seen, WE'RE STILL HERE!
The Print Annual is the cause we rally around to make it happen. It is a collection of the best stories, art and photography of the year from Nowhere. If you are new to Nowhere or haven't had time to keep up over the the last year, this is a way to capture the best of the best. Here's a glimpse of the special 10th Anniversary Print Annual:
David Zoby finds Assad, Rumi and strawberry shisha in Syria
Chris Morgan discovers sable-maned witches & the sea in Wales
Lara Tupper writes about Speedos, Congressmen and Jesus in Maine
Desdemona Dallas photographs a road trip through the American West
Anna Wallace-Thompson navigates crocodiles and taxis in Cairo
Jenni Quilter recounts North African pirates on an Icelandic bike ride
Beejay Silcox makes memories from six yards of fabric in Ghana
To us, travel is not about buying and selling, it is about experiencing. With the 10th Anniversary Print Annual, you will experience the far corners of the world, right from your couch.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Sourcing, editing, printing and distributing a magazine is incredibly difficult these days. Doing it with a staff you can count on one hand, with no financial backing or regular advertising, is even harder. Pure passion for writing and travel fuels Nowhere. That and our readers. We literally couldn't do this without you.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.title: Travel Writing Webinar
support.descp:
Two-hour, comprehensive, live travel writing workshop with Nowhere Editor Porter Fox. How to bring back a great story from your travels. How to organize notes and turn them into narrative. How to craft a story arc, characters, tension, resolution, digressions, backstory and contextual detail. How to self-edit, write a pitch letter and get published. This is a six-week class compressed into one mega-session.

support.title: NORTHLAND: New book by Porter Fox
support.descp:
Get an early release, signed copy of Nowhere Editor Porter Fox's new book, "Northland: A 4,000-Mile Journey Along America's Forgotten Border" (W.W. Norton; ships in June). Following the path of explorers and pioneers—in a canoe, freighter, car and on foot—Fox paints a picture of America's northern borderlands. Throughout, he weaves in his encounters with residents, border guards, American Indian activists and militia leaders to give a dynamic portrait of a northland wracked by climate change, water wars and heightened border security.
INCLUDES:

updates.update_content: People. Place. Time.

Hey Nowhere Backers!
Last reminder that there are 12 hours left to get a signed copy of NORTHLAND and membership in the NORTHLAND Book Club this summer! Read the book that takes you behind the scenes of America's northern border, the longest international border in the world.
Canoeing, hiking, riding, flying, camping in the North Cascades, Rocky Mountains, Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, Montana's Medicine Line, Maine's North Woods, the Saint Lawrence River and the Great Lakes, Idaho and Washington...

Hey Backers-
Some great news: Norton released more signed NORTHLAND books for you to order. Get a signed copy here today.

Hey Backers-
Hope you are enjoying spring and carrying your print annuals around with you! For those who had to wait for theirs, or have yet to receive it, many apologies. A series of long, painful conversations with USPS revealed that not only did they provide us with "dummy" tracking numbers for a third of our orders, about half that many were destroyed or damaged in the mail.

Hey Backers!
We have received a few emails that tracking info on rewards is not up to date. Rest assured that all shipments have gone out and your reward is on the way. Unfortunately, Brooklyn USPS is notoriously slow processing packages. And media mail is typically at the bottom of the heap.
So please be patient. Two weeks to receive a package in the US from Brooklyn is not unheard of...and sometimes tracking info . Sad but true.

campaign.story:
This #Make100 project is my odé to Vienna! It’s my letter to you, friend! It’s me sending you photos of my special places, with notes on why they’re dear to me. It’s the pictures I’ve taken and the secret observations I’ve collected over time. It’s me whispering to you where you should go and what spot you should visit the next time you come to the capital of Austria. 
Vienna is famous for its café culture. It’s world known for the big thinkers who gather around tiny tables to discuss recent political affairs, culture, and literature. And sometimes, of course, gossip - especially when you consider what the Viennese writers wrote about and what the painters painted. But that’s getting a bit off topic... 
I wrote down a list of places, 50 to be exact, that I believe you should honor with a visit. Places where I think you should drink a cup of coffee at least once in your lifetime. There are traditional cafés, hidden gems, and modern third wave coffee shops. They’re places where you might not have thought about going for a coffee, but definitely should. 
Whether you’re a Viennese or someone who’s planning to visit, this is a collection of cards you can easily carry in your pocket or purse to pull out whenever you need inspiration for what to do on a rainy, sunny, lonely, or joyful day with friends, your partner, or just yourself. 
This set of cards will be printed by MOO 100 times. If you follow me on Instagram (@kathmo) you might have already seen some of the shots I’ll include. I’ll add a little diary that I wrote for you and send it to you soon(ish) after this Kickstarter ends. 
  I hope I can inspire you to visit new places and rediscover the forgotten ones! 
 With love from Vienna, 
Monika 
#kathmoscards

updates.update_userinfo: Your package is on the way!
Would you like to learn how to shift your career or how to set out as a freelancer?
updates.update_content:
Last year, I gave a talk at Creative Mornings Vienna explaining how no Plan A has ever worked for me. At the end, I wanted to launch the Kickstarter for my book, Work Trips and Road Trips, which didn’t work. The platform had a major bug, so it proved my point once more. The end of the video is quite devastating. And, hmm, has been online since. Hmpf. 
About a month ago, I launched a campaign for these cards. They went fast. 
When I then told my good friend I was planning to launch a Berlin project to get a better quality of paper, we thought Berlin would be easy. People love coffee. People love Berlin. We didn’t think there was an issue.

updates.update_userinfo: A small update from my desk
updates.update_content:
When I first had the idea for the Vienna project, I went back into my photo archives and found I still needed 19 pictures to be able to go live on Kickstarter. When I then began calculating how to print the Vienna guide on the most beautiful paper, I realized I needed to increase the print run to decrease the costs. That’s when I had the idea to create a Berlin guide. Once again, I went through my archives and found out I only needed 10 more pictures to be able to publish a guide with 50 spots. 
Now I’m sitting here and sorting through all images so that everyone gets the guide they backed for. I really can't wait to hear how you like it. Here are some photos from my desk.

updates.update_userinfo: 3 tips on how to turn strangers into friends
updates.update_content:
Just wanted to share this here as I've just shared it in the Berlin card project and it's not just relevant to Berlin :) 
***
Once you get your Berlin card deck, you won’t just know where to get the best Americano, but also where to meet the best people. Ani, one of my loveliest friends, was a girl reading a book next to me at Katie’s Blue Cat. I was incredibly curious about her, as she was about me. We talked. I simply asked her what she was reading.

updates.update_userinfo: About your Coffee Guide Kickstarter reward
updates.update_content:
Hi there, good morning! 
I just picked up the cards from the post office! It took me a little longer than originally expected because I really wanted an even better quality of paper than their usual business cards. When I first calculated this project, I knew I could only take the better quality if I charged everyone €35 for a set. It felt way too high, so I didn’t. But I couldn’t let go of choosing quality over quantity, so after some calculating and looking up how many of the guides I could hand over in person - and most of all, talking to the super friendly staff at MOO - I managed to find a compromise.

I’ve never really disclosed what cafés I’ve added to the collection of cards, so here are a few I really like where you might want to have a coffee this week:
Schwarzenberg Café: It’s probably one of my favourites and definitely one of the cafés I always take my visitors to. (Or I take them to Prückel or Dommayer.)

updates.update_userinfo: Spoiler alert! ... and some inspiration for this week.
updates.update_content:
Thank you so much for your support! After just 24 hours and since I launched this project, there are already 32 backers. (Yay!) There are only 71 boxes left, so please tell your friends.
As you all know, I’ve been a regular in a number of cafés. I have a bunch I’d call my daily favourites, but I also have places I only go for special occasions. Then, there are spots I love, but where no one would think of going for a coffee. Given the cards have not been printed yet, I’d be curious to know what spot is your favourite. Please share your favourite café in the comments. I might have a story to tell about that one too!

campaign.story:
Three years ago, I had an idea to make a book. That idea grew from a few illustrations that followed a Japanese folk song full narrative and the idea of printing the whole thing with letterpress. Because of Kickstarter, I made that book a reality. 
Shortly after the campaign ended, I had an idea for another book. I've been working on that for the past two years. 
Tama and Kani
Tama
The idea of the story was simply about a little pebble, and how he wanted to be something he wasn't, like his friend Boulder. As I wrote, I did some research. Turns out in Japanese the word Tamaishi (tah-mah-eee-she) is a word that means literally "jewel stone" and metaphorically, a hidden gem or "diamond in the rough". 
That discovery helped me write the story about a little pebble and his path of finding out it's okay to be yourself — a journey from the heights of the valley where all the little things live to the depth of the Great Sea.
Read the first chapter!
I use Ulysses for writing
So what are you making?
Offset, Letterpress & Audiobook
Like before, I want to make three editions:
Offset
 Letterpress 
and Audiobook. 
This time around, the offset edition will include a second spot color. It's a small addition that will help add depth. The letterpress will be still be only one-color, but I'm going to create special limited edition will have handmade watercolor end sheets and a watercolor painting attached to the cover. 
72 Pages this time!
  Not the final design!
Mockup of the casebound version
  I've been focused on the writing and artwork all this time, and now I'm excited to really begin work on the audiobook. Like before, it's more than just reading the words: there are multiple actors, a musical score and sound effects. I used to listen to these kinds of books on tape ( I still have some of them!). And I used to make book reports on tape (Thank you, Ms. Kevra). 
For now, I don't have a sample of this book, but to get an idea of what it will be, please listen to an excerpt from the Zōsan audiobook.
Wait, why not digital printing? 
Digital has its advantages. There are even options to print offset for cheaper than I've ever seen. But I have two motivations: 1) I've always preferred the look and feel uncoated stock, ink in the paper and printing with plates and things that are made by hand. 2) My printing, be it offset or letterpress, is done by artisans of their craft, in the US. It's archival, beautiful, and made by hand.
Letterpress is tactile, subtle, and elegant, with the plates making a noticeable impression in the paper. You can see and feel the difference. Each letterpress impression is hand pulled by an artisan. Then the signatures are hand bound and glued and sewn together. The whole work is a piece of art.
That's really what I want to make again.
What about MAKE/100?
I've added a special hand draw sketch of the characters to those that purchase the audiobook or the twofer - up to 100. This will be drawn on paper using colored pencils as the base and a micron to ink it.
So how's this going to work?
If successfully funded, I'll start making final steps towards production. The writing is done, and the artwork is nearly ready for plates. I'll probably make revisions to both for a few weeks as I start recording the audiobook (reading everything out loud always makes you change things slightly). I've been in communication with the same printers as before and they're both excited to begin. 

I'll begin more focused work on the audiobook — I've got some voice talent lined up, and lots of disparate musical ideas. I can begin recording all the narrator parts and the various characters. 
Plates will made for both printers and I'll begin acquiring all the necessary materials for production: bookcloth, end sheets, headbands, cover stock, etc. Those are all shipped directly to the bookbinders and printers for their use.

Zōsan was such a joy to behold in its final forms. I hope you'll join me in making this next book a reality as well.
—¡™
All the illustrations
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I've been here before. I know the printers and binder and I've been communicating with them for months about this. I know the costs and what it's going to take — and my funding goal reflects that. 

The project is small enough that I can single-handedly manage the fulfillment process. It's actually smaller than the non-profit publication process I used to run a while back (30 some odd books all shipped to Canada and back) — so no worries there!

The audiobook music will be a bit more of a challenge than the last time, since I don't have a folk song melody to work from, but now that the artwork and writing are mostly finished I can concentrate on that.

If funded, the magic begins:
• I'll finalize all the plates and let the printers do their thing.
• I'll get back all the pages and send them to the binder
• I'll press ahead with the audiobook. There's no way I could finish this before the campaign. But while the printers are doing printerly magic, I am free to work on that.

If you have any doubts, please take a quick look at Zōsan! I can't guarantee there will be zero delays, this being an artistic process, but I can guarantee it'll get done. Really all that's left is raising the money for it!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
This project digitally restores 100 rare Civil War glass-negative photographs and offers the high resolution restored digital files and archival-quality prints to the Kickstarter community.

I hope that you will join me in bringing this project to life. Because of my skills in this area and my years of proven success in the online marketplace I know that I can make this project succeed.     
Aug. 1864. Washington, D.C., vicinity. Seven officers by a big gun in a fort.
Photo above with cracked glass, missing emulsion, then after restoration.

Why back this project?
The U.S. Civil War was the first major war to receive substantial photographic coverage. The glass negative “wet-plate process” was not easy. The process involved traveling with large cameras, hand-mixing toxic chemicals, and developing negatives in make-shift darkrooms on horse-drawn wagons. Many of the results were less than ideal.

Nonetheless some of the images that survive are striking. They are worthy of our time and attention. They deserve to be restored to their original condition. This is why I have launched my Make 100 project: Digital Restoration of 100 Rare Civil War Photos. 
Aug. 1863. Bealeton, Virginia. Capt. Cunningham of Gen. T.F. Meagher's staff.
The Process.
I have selected 100 high-interest Civil War photos in need of restoration. I have focused exclusively on collections that have been scanned using professional high-resolution equipment. All 100 photos will come from original public-domain source items dating from 1861 to 1865.

Limiting my selections to high-quality scans, typically high-resolution JPEG or TIFF files, will ensure more accurate restoration along with better quality enlargements.

Spending as much time as needed, I will digitally restore each photo using up-to date software and techniques. Heavily damaged photos or negatives, for example cracked glass negatives or photos with torn or missing pieces, will take significantly longer to restore than negatives in better condition. I will pay careful attention to staying as close to the original photographer’s intent as possible. I will digitally repair scratches, stains, cracks, missing sections, along with restoring original tone and shading. 
April 14, 1865. Ft. Sumter view from parapet.
Photo above with heavy damage stuck on glass slide, then after restoration.

Professional photo restoration which involves Individual attention (vs. automated software) can range from about $35 to $100 per photo. Walgreens charges $39 just to restore one photo.

Once the restoration of the 100 photos is complete I will put all restored high-resolution files on a DVD. Each file will be saved in the optimal file size for an 8 x 10 print (2400 x 3000). I will also produce photo prints on archival paper using a top-rated photo lab known for their work with black and white photography.

Please note that I will NOT be merely printing these out on a home printer. I will be using a professional, premium photo lab that uses archival paper specially designed for continuously-toned black and white prints.
Sept. 1862. Antietam, Maryland. Allan Pinkerton and visitors from Washington (includes Pres. Abe Lincoln).
Timeline.
Jan./Feb.         Research and select the original Civil War photos.
Feb.                  Digitally restore each photo.
March/April    Print archival photos using one of the highest-rated photo
                          developing labs for black and white archival prints.
March/April    Ship to Kickstarter supporters. 
July 9, 1862. James River, Virginia. Officers on deck of U.S.S. Monitor.
Shipping.
I will begin shipping within three weeks after the campaigns ends with the goal of shipping all rewards by April 30th at the latest. All items will be shipped with protective packaging. 
I have been packaging and shipping photos and other items all over the world for more than 18 years.  I have an excellent track record in safely delivering my items to their destination. 
Aug. 1864. Petersburg, Virginia. Cock fighting at Gen. Orlando B. Willcox's headquarters.
Who am I?
I am a husband, a father and a college professor (Ph.D. Philosophy) who spends a good part of my week teaching philosophy and communication courses. Now in my 33rd year of teaching, I enjoy balancing my academic life with family activities and pursuing research interests like historical photographs. I am also active on eBay and Discogs under the user ID SocratesofAthens.
Final thought.
When we can restore historical items from over 160 years ago we pay homage to those photographers who had a strong sense of history; they knew that their messages would resonate with generations far into the future.

I want to offer something of historical value at a reasonable cost. For about the cost for two people to go out to the movies you can own 100 high-resolution restored Civil War photos on DVD. I have also included rewards that involve archival printed copies.  I hope that you will join me on this project and help keep photographic history alive.

Thanks so much for your support!.
1865. Washington, D.C. View across Chain Bridge over the Potomac.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Project Risks: 
For you, the supporter of this project, the risk is almost non-existent. 

I am an honest person with a proven track record that you can verify online. I have earned consistently high feedback selling photos and antiques on eBay for over 18 years and selling vinyl records on Discogs for about 3 years, both under the user ID, SocratesOfAthens. Please check out my feedback. My online business policy is rather simple: do the right thing all the time.

Project Challenges:
The process of digital restoration involves skill, patience and perseverance. Quality restoration is also a time-consuming process. I am a bit of a perfectionist. I use the latest version of Photoshop and I give individual attention to each photo. My challenge will be to manage my time so that I can work diligently over the next several months to fulfill all orders by the end of April 2018.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
The Original 1967 NASA Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Chart Restored, Recolored, and Reissued.
2019 will mark the 50th anniversary of one of the most monumental events in the history of mankind - The Apollo 11 Project - the first landing of humans on the moon. This Kickstarter campaign is a celebration of that accomplishment. 
In 1967, two years before the first man set foot on the moon, NASA had charted the entire route that the command module "Columbia" and the landing module "Eagle" would make on its journey from earth to the moon and back home again and released it as a poster. This chart has now been fully restored, recolored, and - with your support - will be launched as a special reissue. 
The Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Chart
  On July 20, 1969, two American astronauts ( Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin ) became the first men to step foot on the moon. It was a dream and a challenge set forth by one man, President John F. Kennedy, when he declared in May of 1961 : 
"I believe this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal, before this decade is out, of landing a man on the moon and returning him safely to earth."
It took years of planning and the work of thousands of people to accomplish this task but on July 16th the massive Saturn V rocket lifted off from NASA's Kennedy Space Center carrying three astronauts on their mission to the moon.
"All this is possible only through the blood, sweat, and tears of a number of people.... All you see [are] the three of us, but beneath the surface are thousands and thousands of others."
                                             - Apollo 11 astronaut Michael Collins 
Thousands of people across America and the world watched in anticipation, and all those years of planning culminated in celebration on that exciting day.
Spiro Agnew and Lyndon Johnson Watching the Launch
  The Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Chart proves how well planned out the project was even two years prior to when the Saturn V launched the capsule into space. Stages of the launch, orbit, descent, and return were precisely calculated...and those who owned this chart at the time could have followed along with the astronauts on every leg of the journey. 
This chart is a wonderful paper souvenir of one of the most glorious events in humankind and yet very few people own it. So I hope to change that with this project. 
I have fully restored this original lunar landing chart, bringing out the deep blacks of outer space, and the details of the capsule drawings. Then I changed the hues of the earth and moon ( to give it that added sci-fi punch ) and colored the text and lines, adding plenty of "stars" too. 
A fifty-year-old chart given new life.....it deserves it. 
This reissue of The Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Chart will measure 1' x 3' ( 12" x 36"/30cm x 92cm ). It will be printed on 80lb glossy cover stock with a UV coating and feature a 1/4" border - in black - so it will be easy to frame. The title block will also feature foil stamping to really commemorate the occasion. This is a standard panorama frame size as well, so pre-made frames can easily be purchased. 
Detail from The Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Chart
  Detail from The Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Chart
  Simple rewards for a humble, but worthy, project......
THE STICKER SET - $5
One 4" circular sticker featuring the original artwork from the Apollo 11 mission patch. The astronauts had wanted the image on the patch to be symbolic so they chose a bald eagle with its "landing gear" extended. The eagle is a proud symbol of the United States but it was also the name of the lunar module. To symbolize the peaceful nature of the mission, the eagle is carrying an olive branch - the symbol of peace. 
Also, included will be two 3" x 6" stickers of the original Apollo 11 logo. 
THE APOLLO 11 LUNAR LANDING CHART - $30
One Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Chart + the sticker set. This is what this project is all about. It measures 12" x 36" ( 30cm x 92cm ) and will come shipped rolled in a tube. As a bonus, you'll also receive all of the stickers!
 THE APOLLO 11 LUNAR LANDING CHART X2 - $60
Two ( 2 ) Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Charts + two ( 2 ) sticker sets. Double the charts, double the stickers.
THE APOLLO 11 PROJECT SET ( Limited to 100 ) - $50 
Two ( 2 ) Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Charts + two ( 2 ) sticker sets + one ( 1 ) 11x14" double-sided poster featuring images of the original concept artwork of the landing and command modules. A bonus poster, plus a discount! This is a Kickstarter exclusive. 
While this project is listed under my name - Constance Metzinger - it will actually be a joint effort by my sister, Diana, and myself. I enjoy the restoration work, all design aspects of the project, and handling "customer service" while Diana takes care of packaging duties. Currently, she is running her own Kickstarter campaign called The Past in Focus which also deals with history - restoring historic photographs. I hope you take the time to check out her project! 
I'd like to thank NASA for generously providing images of the Apollo 11 project and special thanks to all of the men and women involved in the various Apollo projects from its beginning in 1966.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
My sister and I operate a photo business and we are constantly packaging prints and posters for our customers, so order fulfillment is not an issue for us. 

The chart has already been restored, so no snags there. The printer that I will be working with always does amazing work, so no worries there. In truth, I foresee no visible delays in launching this project, except in the event of a meteor crashing to earth or a health calamity falling upon me ( I hope not! ). 

Our last project - The Spotting Chart Project - was accomplished and fulfilled on time, and - by george! - this one will be too!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
The lunar landing charts have all been launched into transit with the last shipment having been sent off just two days ago. So the project is officially complete! Of course, if you didn't answer the survey you will still be receiving your chart once I know where to send it to.
This shipment stage took a little longer than expected due to the volume of packages being sent off so I thank all of you for your patience. Next year marks the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing and if you have an interest in similar projects to this one, stay tuned, for I have a big Apollo space project in the works!

The first shipment of lunar charts is on its way! 
The charts and stickers arrived earlier this week and all of them look really nice! The printer did an excellent job with the charts and I hope all of you will be as pleased with the result as I am! 
A few little notes......

On February 24th this humble project was not only successfully funded but went way beyond expectations....with 801 backers supporting it!  Wowee! 
Thank you to each and every one of you for making the reissue of this chart a reality. It would not have gone into production without you. Which leads me to the update: the charts are in their printing stage right now, and the stickers are, too. Once they arrive and are inspected, I'll be purchasing mailing tubes and then off they will fly to your homes!

campaign.story:
Sample of the Box
There will only be 250 copies of this game printed.
It is the summer of 1814 and the British Navy controls the Chesapeake Bay. With that navy is a small professional army, fresh from the battlefields of Europe and Napoleonic warfare, ready to land on the shores along the bay and bring this war to an end. Their targets are Norfolk, Washington and Baltimore, the heart of American ship building and maritime industry. Standing in their way is a large disorganized militia and a handful of marines. The historical campaign resulted in Washington being burned. But now the decisions are yours……   
Our War of 1812 Campaigns uses the game system from our Blue and Gray series adapted to this era. War Along the Chesapeake is Volume 1 and will be followed later by Volume 2: War Along the Great Lakes and Volume 3: War Along the Gulf Coast.
Our number one goal on this project is to get you your game very, very SOON. Our goal is a delivery in March or April.
All Kickstarter backers will receive a book on the campaign using excerpts from Henry Adams classic "A History of the United States during the Administrations of Jefferson and Madison".  
KICKSTARTER EXCLUSIVE

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Worthington has completed over 20 kickstarter campaigns. We have been in business for 14 years now and have produced over 50 games. The biggest challenge faced is always in dealing with the printer and shipping. Delays can occur and always being up front with customers and letting them know what is going on is critical.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

comments.content: I don't completely agree on what constitutes victory in the war. I suspect the British were just fine on how things turned out. They never made a serious shot at Baltimore given that preliminary matters didn't turn out as planned. They just left with minimal losses and the belief that they had responded to the burning of York. I don't think they would have considered the result to be a marginal American victory in the slightest, and it is hard to claim a marginal victory when your capital is burned down. However, it is game and a game needs to define victory, so I am good with it. I do hope that the upcoming campaign in Niagra defines victory a bit differently, as the result of the actual campaign that occurred can only be considered a decisive defeat for the US. Remember, the British occupied pretty much the border states during the peace conference. Anything short of at least occupying some of Canada (which matters, like York, Kingston etc..) should be considered a defeat for the US.

After reading the rules I can’t figure out the point of reserves. The rules allude to reserves joining other battles, but this concept is not discussed further. Anyone have any idea why anyone would ever keep a reserve?

The defenders on Hampstead Hill were furiously digging in so they sent General Stricker and a delaying force to the North Point peninsula to delay the British advance. During the subsequent Battle of North Point some American sharpshooters killed British General Robert Ross. It would be a shame not to have that as an option for the U.S. forces. Fort McHenry, because of geography, was only able to be attacked from the sea(actually, the Patapsco River). Attacking the city from the West would have been a difficult march for the British plus they would have lost contact with the fleet. So it had to be an assault from the East. It had two components. The reduction of the fort by the fleet and the land campaign by the Army. It would be better in my opinion to keep the two separate if possible.

That being said, I am still on the fence on this one. I haven't played the Blue and Gray Campaign Series enough to know how much I want this one :-). I love War of 1812 games, but have more interest in the Great Lakes campaign.

#Make100     Birds YOU will Never See

These are paintings of birds you and your family..and future family will never get a chance to see again....   A lot of reasons can attribute to their extinction.

updates.update_userinfo: New Reward over on my new Make100 adventure!!
updates.update_content:
Sad Little Frog Love
NEW REWARD!! SAD LITTLE FROG LOVE  A new reward is now OPEN over on my next adventure! Make 100 Amphibians and Reptiles! To celebrate meeting the 1/2 way point for funding for this the project! 
THANK YOU for checking it out!

I had to share this one from my newest project.   It makes me laugh!!    This is n0. 8 Starry Night Toad (only the real art nerds will get this one)
Enjoy!!

Hello Bird Friends,
I started a new adventure today!!  Make 100 Amphibians and Reptiles You Will Never See Again.  It is alot like the bird project, but I thought these little ones should get a voice as well.  I hope you come check out my new project and stay for the fun!! 
Take care,

updates.update_userinfo: A NEW Adventure and a RESTART!!
updates.update_content:
Hello Bird Friends,
I am restarting, renewing my next Make 100!  I realized making 100 Trump Hairs was wearing me down...I had to cancel it.  I  am excited for this new adventure!    The idea is close to the birds, (but larger originals, 5" x 7")  it is ... Make 100 Disappearing Animals.  I hope you come check out this new beginning!  I am ready to take this to 100!  I am once again inspired, and have so much planned on this new adventure.  I have already started n0 4 in the collection!

updates.update_userinfo: A new year.. and a new project!!
updates.update_content:
Hello 100 Birds You will Never See Again folks!  I hope everyone has had a great start to the 2019 year.  I wanted to send you a note to check out my next Make 100 campaign here on Kickstarter... I just launched it yesterday! I am very excited to try and paint 100 of these.
It is  Make 100 Endangered Animals with Presidential Hair... or as some have called it the Trump collection.  These all will be animals that are still around.. but struggling, and yes all 100 will be with presidential hair.

Hello Friends,
  I hope by now everyone is enjoying the 100 Birds You Will Never See Again.  This series was such a great project and your support kept me inspired.
  Through a surgery (and 6 week recovery), a family member passing away, and some major damage here at the farm from weather.... I was determined to get everything out to everyone.  Thank you again for your patience and understanding.  This was my first adventure here... and I hope to have more to come.

updates.update_userinfo: Thank you, Thank you, Thank you!!
updates.update_content:
Hello 100 Bird Friends!
  Just a late Sunday (early Monday) update.  Thank you for all the kind words and continued support as I am getting all your birds out.  I am glad everyone is enjoy the little extra care and surprises in each package.  With so many orders traveling in all parts of the world, this truly has been wonderful.  I appreciate everyone's patience and understanding as packages are being shipped.   Please continue to send me updates here or even on Poordogfarm Facebook and Instagram.

Hello Friends,
Just a quick update. Almost all prints have been mailed or are leaving. All Randoms Birds in all categories are mailed. All Ned and Martha prints are mailed as well!! I am still working on matting and framing a bunch of the you pick. The Singe You Picks in mats left last week. Doubles and you pick 5 in mars are leaving this week. The goal is to have all prints out this week.

Thanks again to everyone that has been checking in! I huge batch of birds left yesterday as well as another batch today.
I included some surprises in your orders as well.. a thank you, for being so understanding and patient. This was my first Kickstarter... and the success was great!! I didn’t realize these birds would be such a great idea! The printing, packaging, and mailing is quite a job!! I am excited to hear what you think of the 100 Birds You Will Never See Again.

Hello Friends,
  Just a short updated today!  More and more Birds You Will Never See are leaving the farm!  So much work!!    At this point most have been matted and framed, and packaged!  There are a few leaving tomorrow and a few more leaving this week. Thank you again for your patience and understanding during this process.  I can't wait for everyone to get their art!  I hope you will enjoy the birds!!

campaign.story:
What will you get out of it?
From the seemingly endless archives of the Library of Congress, I will find a photo you’ve never seen before but that you would absolutely want to have hanging on your wall. I will pick a photo specifically for you and 99 other backers, according to your personal wishes.
South Water Street Illinois Central Railroad freight terminal, Chicago, Illinois / By Jack Delano / 1943
Do you want a photo of a striking skyline? Of a landscape, animals, workers, factories? Should it specifically be a photo of a mine in Utah in the 1970s? You decide, and I will do my best to fulfill your wishes. Alternatively, you can let me decide and be surprised. With your help, I will create a collection of 100 photos of the United States of America.
Bingham Canyon Mine, Copperton, Utah / Unknown Photographer / 1972
If large photo prints aren’t your thing, you can still support this endeavor in return for a single postcard – or a set of five postcards. And if large photo prints are really your thing, you can get one of five huge 20×30" prints, also selected specifically for you.
The photos will be printed on high-quality photo paper, leaving a small white border on the prints to allow for easy framing. Each print and postcard will note the photo’s location, and if available its photographer and creation date, on the back.
Why am I doing this? 
The United States are a vast, incredibly beautiful country. I’m living here now, but as a foreigner, it still often seems to me that I’m on a movie set. I’ve been fascinated by the Library of Congress’ photo archive of this country’s nature, architecture, and people for years. With this Kickstarter project, I’m combining my love for America’s beauty with my interest in the Library’s photo collection.
Over the years I’ve traversed that archive for weeks on end, so I know my way around it. I created personal photo books and ran a blog with photos from the archive. I’m currently sharing shop window type and lettering from the archive on Twitter.
How will I find your perfect photo?
You will fill out a questionnaire giving me both basic parameters as well as more specific ideas that you’d love to see matched, too. I expect to always being able to find photos matching a basic motive choice or a location by state. Or you let me surprise you!
Left: Questa, New Mexico / John Collier /1943 — Right: Drillers at Fort Loudoun Dam, Tennessee / Jack Delano / 1942
The photography archive has its limitation, so while I will try to match more specific points like the exact place and year, I can’t guarantee that. You might want a photo of three horses, but might end up with a photo of four horses in front of a beautiful mountain. That still sounds pretty good, right?
Why should you back this project?
With your help I will be able to take this journey into the Library’s archive and create a collection of 100 beautiful photos from around the country. As a labor of love, this project aims to shine a light on the Library of Congress, to help them continue their mission of preserving and sharing knowledge and history.
Million Dollar Bridge, Cordova, Alaska / Jet Lowe / 1984
In the end, the project will create a body of 100 photos from the Library of Congress’ archives, only connected by the thread of your questionnaires and my selection. I hope to exhibit these photos on the web and in a physical space in NYC later in 2018.
Why wouldn’t you just print photos from the archive yourself?
Works by the U.S. Government are not eligible for U.S. copyright protection, which is how I am able to share my appreciation for the archive with you. But you can use the archive yourself, too, so please do!
Many of the Library of Congress’ photos are available as high resolution image files for anyone to download, adapt, print, etc. I absolutely want to encourage you to delve into the archive yourself!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I know the archive well, and I know how to find what I’m looking for despite the sometimes lacking meta information. But I cannot guarantee that I will be able to exactly fulfill all your specific ideas. If I’m not able to fulfill even your basic parameters (basic motive or state), I will offer you three alternative photos that I find fit your ideas the best and will let you decide.

Part of this project’s charm is that you invest into a yet unknown piece of art. Will you love your photo? I certainly hope so! But I can’t guarantee it.

I will work with a U.S. based, high-quality printer that will produce and ship your prints and postcards. I will not be able to control each print myself before they reach you, but will do my best to solve any printing and shipping problems we encounter.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Rewards
As of a week ago, all rewards have been sent out. If you still haven’t received your print or your postcard set, please message me so we can figure out where it went wrong. And if you’re one of the few who haven’t filled out their reward surveys, please do so as soon as possible, or by the end of May latest.
Website
In other exciting news, I have created a website for One Hundred Views of America. On the website you can see all the photos I’ve selected for you and other print backers and learn more about each of the photos.

The Kickstarter campaign is ending on Wednesday, so I wanted to take this moment to thank you all for your support so far! I’m so excited to find photos for all backers of the print tiers (currently 58), and to send out postcards to all the other backers.
Surveys will go out to all of you in the days after the campaign ends. Postcard-level backers will be asked for their addresses, and print backers will receive the more elaborate questionnaire to help me find a great photo for you.

campaign.story:
Ever wonder where museums came from? Appearing in Renaissance Europe, the 'cabinet of curiosities' is an early ancestor of the modern museum.
Cabinet of Curiosities 1599, 1690
A Cabinet of Curiosities or - wunderkammer - stored and exhibited a wide variety of objects, with a particular leaning towards the rare, eclectic and esoteric. Modern terminology would categorize the objects included as belonging to natural history (sometimes faked with objects like dragon's blood or unicorn horns), geology, ethnography, archaeology or historical relics and antiquities. 
Working around this cool subject matter, creating/collecting pieces for a personal version of a wunderkammer became exciting! It took months of work but wanting to create a unique art deck it was well worth the time spent. 
Cabinet of Curiosities - Alabaster Deck
Inside the Cabinet of Curiosities art deck is a complete series of 54 fully illustrated and imagined objects inspired by the works and personal collections of naturalists and explorers. 
  Each card from this deck is a juxtaposition of elements such as mechanisms coupled with an organic look that inexplicably forms a truly unique and obscure object. 
Jokers & 2 of Diamonds
      Cabinet of Curiosities - Court Cards
    Card Backs & Queen of Spades
      Features:
Printed and Fulfilled by NPCC
Limited to 1000 decks "no reprints"
54 fully illustrated cards & 1 double backer
Premium German Cardstock
Matte Finished Tuckbox
Custom Perforated Tax Stamp Seal
*Embossed Tuck
*Inner Tuck Print 
*stretch goals
      You can help make this Cabinet of Curiosities playing card deck a reality. It's in your hands how this dream can be materialized. Sharing this project with your friends is a huge help that can get us closer to our goals!
All artworks are complete with just a few tweaks to be made. Our personal timeline for this is to have all rewards to be delivered by May 2018. We're just looking at getting those stretch goals to immediately start production. Here's a rough rundown.
Designs will be sent and printed by NPCC this February. They will also do the fulfillment so that will be a good thing since they're great with that. We have a pretty good relationship with them and have seen a fast production on their projects and their quality looks great. We also choose them for their manageable production costs and flow which we needed for this project. The cards should be ready within March and since postal services are not hampered by the holidays anymore around April this should alleviate problems for the transit of parcels globally. 

We have made enough wiggle room for a June shipping but our personal timeline is to get everything shipped starting April to May. 

Follow Us Here!
Cellar Window's Instagram
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have created a lot of decks and personally created 4 projects and this will be our fifth. Having said that we're no strangers to delays and the last two of our projects is facing these problems but are currently on their last manufacturing phase and are slated to be shipped in the next months ahead. We have learned to keep backers updated for all our projects and we will do this and be as transparent as we can going forwards. With a new manufacturer specifically chosen for this project and a more experienced team on our part we are extremely confident in our supplier and in our goal to make this our personal best turn around for Cellar Window from funding to shipping. We will try to beat our June shipping estimate! All the designs in Cabinets of Curiosities are finished and ready to be sent to NPCC for printing like we stated and they will be handling the manufacturing and fulfillment of the decks too which makes it a very streamlined process. 

*Artworks seen here are renderings and although mirrors the final outcome, slight changes are expected like color etc as the main product is produced.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Take your pick from 100 rare photos of the past that I will restore to crisp perfection. 
What is The Past in Focus about? 
Thousands upon thousands of magnificent images from the past are buried in photo archives across America and the world. They deserve to be displayed and marveled at....and they deserve to be restored and seen in hi-definition.
The ship Garthsnaid weathering a storm ( 1920 )/National Library of New Zealand
I will unearth 100 rarely-seen images from these archives and give them new life by digitally restoring them to their original splendor. You can help me select these photos and then you will have the choice of any of the 100 restored images to own as a print. Together, we'll be archaeologists sifting through the sands of time and discovering rare photographic jewels to polish and bring to life again. 
What Kind of Images Are Being Restored?
Sailing ships, arctic explorers, adventurers in Africa, magnificent buildings, workers and laborers, thoughtful portraits, beautiful scenery from America's national parks, aviation images, captured moments from the era of the wild west ..... anything unique, truly eye-catching, and RARE. The rarer the juicier. 
The Ghost Town of Eureka, Colorado ( 1900 ) by William Henry Jackson/Detroit Publishing Company Archives
This project is as much yours as it is mine, so if there is a particular image ( or a general subject ) you want to see included, spit it out and let me know! I'll hunt for a matching image and then you can tell me whether you believe it should be in the collection or not. 
Juan Domenjos flying an Antionette airplane ( 1915 )/Harris & Ewing Collection
  A streetside view of Saratoga Springs, NY ( 1915 )/Detroit Publishing Company Archives
Picking Your Print
At the conclusion of the campaign, all 100 of the restored images from "The Past in Focus" will be available for viewing online and you can then make your pick of which image you want to frame for your home. Enjoy a mystery? I can surprise you with a print! 
If you can't decide which photo you would like to own, then you can own them all - The Past in Focus Image Collection will include all 100 images fully-restored as hi-res jpegs ( 1200-2500px ) so you can make 5x7" or 8x10" prints yourself. Only 100 of The Past in Focus Image Collections will be available. 
An Italian mother with her child at Ellis Island, NY ( 1905 ) by Lewis Wickes Hine/Preus Museum
  The majority of these images will be unearthed from the largest and most magnificent photo collection in America - the Library of Congress - but I will peruse libraries from the far corners of the world as well... libraries such as the Rijksmuseum, the National Maritime Archives of Australia, and The British Library. 
Grafton Street, Dublin ( 1903 )/National Library of Ireland
  A Jewett touring car in the San Francisco area ( 1923 )/Wyland Stanley Collection
  Libraries make it a practice to scan photographs and then upload them to their archives untouched and unrestored. Most need color correction, sharpening, and a great deal of spot cleaning to bring them to vibrant life again. It takes me anywhere from 10-45 minutes to clean and restore each photo. If "The Past in Focus" gets successfully funded, I'll be taking time off from my small business to focus on the digital restoration of these 100 images. 
Scratches, specks, and other damage is repaired one click at a time
The photos shown on this page are just a sample of some of the past restoration work I have done.
Photographer Marion Post Wolcott on assignment in Kentucky ( 1940 )/Library of Congress
  My sister and I operate a home-based photo business, so making beautiful photographs is our specialty. All 8x10" and 16x20" prints** will be printed and cut by hand in our home studio. They will be printed on Canon premium luster photo paper with Chromalife inks ( 150+ year lifespan ). All photos are archival so you'll have a print that one day will be as old as the image printed on it! 
**If there are more than 30 orders than all 16x20" photos will be printed by a professional U.S based photo printer. 
Three-masted ships in formation ( 1899 )/Library of Congress
  A grotto in an iceberg ( British Antarctic Expedition, 1911 )/National Library of New Zealand
  The Past in Focus has reached its goal! In order to spice up the collection, I've added Bonus Sets. Every time we reach a new goal level a bonus set will be added to the collection. If you have already backed the project then these photos are a bonus reward! ( Backers who selected the print option will be able to select from these images as well ). Check back here often because every few days a new bonus set will be added! 
NOTE: If you do not wish to select a print or The Past in Focus Image Collection, these sets are available individually under the "Bonus Set" reward option. 
If the project reaches $2500.....
 ....then SHIPS AND THE SEA will be added. This set of 12 hand-picked photos will feature beautiful three-masted schooners, yachts, and brigantines sailing the seven seas. 
If the project reaches $3000.....
...then THE AGE OF EXPLORATION will be added. This set of 15 hand-picked photos will feature images of explorers and hardy pioneers of foreign lands such as Africa, Australia, South America, and the polar regions. 
If the project reaches $3500.....
....then HOW BIZARRE! will be added. This set of 10 hand-picked photos will feature images of the strange, unusual - and downright bizarre! 
If the project reaches $4000.....
....then INTO THE SKIES will be added. This beautiful set of 15 hand-picked photos will feature images from the early days of aviation: aeroplanes, gliders, bi-planes, blimps, balloons, and the pilots that flew them.
If the project reaches $4500.....
....then THE LAND DOWN UNDER will be added. This set of 15 hand-picked photos will feature images of Australia in all its glory: landscapes, city views, the people, culture, and, of course, kangaroos!
If the project reaches $5000....
....then NEW YORK, NEW YORK will be added. This set of 18 beautiful images will feature scenes of the Big Apple dating back to the mid-1800s. See New York like you never saw it before! 
If the project reaches $5500....
...then SEASIDE HOLIDAY will be added. This set of 10 images will feature lovely scenes of happy beachgoers, lighthouses, and toe-dipping youngsters at the seaside. 
WOW! We made $6000 without a stretch goal....
....but you're still going to receive a bonus set, of course. This time it's 12 images of Mother Nature in all her glory: waterfalls, mountains, geysers, volcanoes, etc. 
And since the campaign passed $6500....
...another set just got added! Choo-choo, we're steaming ahead! A set of 12 beautiful images of trains from around the world. 
If the campaign reaches $7500....
The Past in Focus Photobook
....a new reward level will be offered. Requests for the photobook have been heard! I wouldn't want the assembling of the book to distract from the restoration work of the photos so it will have a longer fulfillment date ( April ) but anyone who would rather own the book featuring all 100 images from The Past in Focus Image Collection will be able to switch their reward at this level. It will be a hardcover, glossy, 115-page photobook with a very limited print-run of 100. Would you like your name in the book? You deserve it, so just let me know and you'll be accredited as an official restoration sponsor! 
Since we passed $8500.....
...another bonus set just got added! SMALLTOWN AMERICA will feature 15 beautiful images from small hamlets across the USA. 
$10,000! ......
....at that level we all deserve a JOURNEY AROUND THE WORLD! Let's see, we'll have to make a stop in England, the Continent, India, Africa, Asia, and certainly South America. Twenty images, twenty ports of call. 
If the project reaches $12,000.....
.....then it's time to have a spot of recreation. The A GOOD SPORT collection will feature 12 beautifully restored images of sports: auto racing, tennis, golf, horse jumping, boxing, etc. 
If the project reaches $13,000.....
....then A VIEW OF THE HEAVENS will be added. My sister just launched her Kickstarter campaign - The Apollo 11 Lunar Landing Chart - so this is sort of a tie-in celebration of space. It will include 12 amazing photos of observatories, early space photographs ( can you believe that moon image was taken before 1920? ), rare NASA images, and astronomers in action. 
Spread the word about the project and more and more photos will be added to The Past in Focus Image Collection!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my first Kickstarter project but my sister and I had previously teamed up to create The Spotting Chart Project, a campaign which was successfully funded by pledgers like you back in February 2017. We managed to fulfill all of the orders for that project within one month and since photos are our specialty, this project should be fulfilled in even less time. However, to be on the safe side, I have made allowance for 4-6 weeks.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Ready to embark on The Grand Tour?
updates.update_content:
The Second Edition to "The Past in Focus" is complete! 
It took several months longer than planned but I think you will be pleased with the images. While a few of them may be familiar to you history buffs, I really strove to find the rarest photos I could. Many of the images are from glass-plate negatives from the Library of Congress, others are from old prints from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the National Libraries of Norway, Finland, Sweden, Australia, and other countries.

updates.update_userinfo: The Second Edition Is On Its Way!
updates.update_content:
It's time for some news, and here is the latest scoop: 
The images have all been restored, the survey closed yesterday ( if you haven't yet answered it, no worries, it's still open for you ) and shipping has begun! Postman Pat will be kept busy for the next few weeks delivering all of these photos around the world!

It's "pick"ture time! The images are slowly coming together but instead of waiting for them all to be completely clean before unveiling them I thought I'd let the photos trickle in as they are being finished. This way you can pan for gold one day at a time....or wait a week and view them all at once.
The project is nearly over ( only 38 hours to go! ) so now is the time for a little feedback and a few announcements :

campaign.story:
HELLO MY NAME IS KAZ MATSUNE   
Thank you for taking your time, considering to support this book project.
I am the owner and chef of Breakthrough Sushi in San Francisco.
I started my Sushi career in 2000 with no Sushi or culinary experience. After the first three years of intensive training, I met so many exceptional Sushi Chefs who taught me the secrets of Sushi making. They also taught me the work ethics and philosophy of Japanese hospitality.
In 2008, I started teaching Sushi classes because I wanted to share and pass my knowledge to others. My first class had only three participants, but it was a start. I found out that there are so many people who want to learn Sushi but they simply do not know where to start, like how to get ingredients as fresh fish.
This prompted me to started Breakthrough Sushi, the first and only Sustainable Sushi Class company in the US. The year was 2011. After six years in business, we've served over 7,000 guests both corporate and private clients, teaching and showing how to make and eat Sushi.
We are a very small company, but I feel so fortunate to have so many big name clients like Google, Facebook, Pinterest, Prudential, Chevrolet, and Citibank.
Then about two years ago, I starting answering Sushi questions on Quora, an online site known as "A place to share knowledge and better understand the world." I enjoyed writing my answers so much so that before soon, I have written several hundred answers which were published in HuffingtonPost and Slate:
Why I Love Making Sushi More Than Eating It
The Best Sushi Tips and Etiquette From a Real Sushi Chef
Which Types of Sushi Best Test a Sushi Chef’s Abilities?
I put some of the answers together, which became my first book, "All the Answers You Always Wanted to Hear from Your Sushi Chef."
    While I enjoyed writing those answers on Quora, I realized people are interested in my story of how I learned the art of Sushi making. My desire to share my story grew more and more, so I started writing my experience little by little, every day.
I'VE WRITTEN A MEMOIR
Two years passed. Now, I have written over 100,000 words and planning to add another 20,000 words to finish the story.
Here is the outoine of the book. All written, except the last chapter, "Sushi Class."
OPENING
SUSHI TRAINING
Interviews
The First Day
The First Evening T
he Second Day
American Style Sushi
My First California Roll
COOKING AND SUSHI TECHNIQUES
My first memory of Sushi
Mother’s Cooking
Rainbow Rolls
Yanagiba, Sushi Knife
Sashimi
Katsuo & Kohada
Makanai
Tamago
Fugu Fresh fish does not aleays taste the best
Maguro
SEX, DRUGS, ROCK 'N' ROLL AND SUSHI
The Baby Girl
Shauna
Lunch with my favorite waitress
A Movie date
The Christmas Party
Celebrities
Strippers
Sushi, Drugs and Rock ‘n Roll
Sake Bombs
Special Orders
Denny’s Rockin
Sushi Chefs
Caucasian Sushi Chef
Iroha Sushi of Tokyo
Ken, Eiji, and Toru at Yoshida Sushi
Go-san
Jin-san
Take-san
SUSHI CLASS
LA to SF
My first Sushi Class
Breakthrough Sushi
Here are some samples of unedited writings, which will go into the book (Quora blog).
I wanted to share my story of how, even someone like me, who is clumsy and disorganized, could learn to become a Sushi Chef and teach others how to make sushi.
The book is packed with the sushi training and techniques, great Sushi chefs and teachers I met, the relationship I had with a waitress, celebrity customers, sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll (yes, the restaurant was on Sunset Strip in Hollywood, right next to a strip club.)
I want to reach out as many people as I can through this book, so it's important that the story is captivating, entertaining and educational at the same time. Because this is my first attempt to make a memoir book, I feel I need some help organizing a story.
This is where the editor comes into rescue me and my book. Yay!
SO I FOUND A GREAT EDITOR
I found this great editor in the UK. The editor asked me not to disclose the name because if I do, it will expose the editing fee, which affects the editor's business and other clients. But I can tell you the cost to edit this book is BP £4.500/US $6,000.
I INVITE YOU TO HELP ME COMPLETE THE STORY
This is where you come in. I am asking for your help to raise the money to hire the editor to finish the book.
The current estimate to finish the book is six months, so we expect the book to complete in August 2018.
I am going to publish it on Amazon Kindle Publishing. Digital and Print version will be available, US$12.99 fror Kindle, $18.99 for Print.
Any extra money raised, I will use to hire a designer to format the book, and market it.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The only challenge is to meet my August, 2018 publishing deadline. 

Until editor reads the manuscript, we don't know exactly how long it would take to finish editing. However, the current estimate is less than six months. This may change based on the other projects the editor is working on. 

Assuming I get the funding in February and the editor finishes all the other projects by then, we expect the book to be ready and published by August 2018.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Unlike that nightmare we keep having, our campaign has finally come to an end. We want to thank you all for making this experience unforgettable. Please, visit our website for continuous updates, including Side Effects expansion packs and brand new games: pillboxgames.com
Get revenge. Gang up on the strong. Protect the weak. Make deals and break them. Enjoy the thrill of giving your friend Impotence!   
First, each player gets 4 Disease cards face up. This is your Psyche.
You’re an impotent, anxious individual with a gambling addiction and the occasional thought of suicide.
You start with a hand of 4 cards and pick up two more each turn.
Oh boy! You got a drug for anxiety; you can take that lorazepam and start chilling out again.
But just as you thought you were getting all better, lorazepam is a cruel lady, she opens you up to 3 more diseases. Lucky for you, you’re already suffering from suicidal thoughts, so the only side effects that can affect you are depression and madness.
Now, it’s your opponent’s turn, and he noticed your list of side effects and added depression to your Psyche. Maybe you can use your Therapy card to treat your depression—just beware, Therapy doesn’t prevent you from getting it again. #Relapse 
You could have treated that depression with a depression drug, but that, too, contains side effects.
Be the first to treat all the diseases in your Psyche and win! Check out this playthrough to see the game in action...
Wow, what a sweet box! That’s what all your friends and doctors will be saying when they get a look at your premium edition, wooden, Side Effects box. Each box is crafted by Marc Charisse with original artwork by Ben Bronstein. They’re made in America, and unfortunately shipping these outside the country is prohibitively expensive—so as of right now, these are only available in the USA.  
Jade Shames came up with the initial idea and basic mechanics for the game. You can read about his personal experiences with mental illness and his reasoning for making a game featuring this topic in his essay "This Is Why I Created a Card Game About Mental Illness", published on Thought Catalog.  
Our motto is beautifully designed, slightly offensive. We specialize in making “playable art” with a sense of humor. Side Effects is the first game for Pillbox Games. We’re 4 Brooklynites (yes, more hipsters making games—we’re [ironically] sorry) dedicated to turning our motto into a successful independent game company.
We have more games in the works, including a Side Effects expansion pack (hint: NSFW), a global warming profiteering game, and Mud, a game lampooning the US presidential election process.
With this successful Kickstarter, we hope to have the support and backing to continue making more games. Kickstarter does not allow us to donate any of these profits to charity, but our ultimate aim is to support local organizations that speak to the themes of each game we create. Side Effects efforts will support mental health, our global warming game will go toward environmental charities, and so on. 
Jen Igartua is unlikely to understand cultural references from the 90's due to the fact that she still super Spanish. Her daytime hustle is to operationalize businesses, her night time hustle we can't talk about here. She's really into overcooked, she likes this game, too, I guess.
Jade Shames is a writer and musician. In 2011, he received a creative writing scholarship to attend The New School, where he received his MFA in 2013. In 2016, he wrote himself into the X-Files expanded universe with the story Give Up the Ghost, published in X-Files: Secret Agendas. He lives in Brooklyn and enjoys a good card game.
Kat Thek is a writer, artist, and detective. Her work has been featured on NPR, CNN, Vice, and Playboy. She received her MA from Brooklyn College in 2013 but still tried to get this Kickstarter featured in Harvard's alumni newsletter. She is always down to play a game.
Ben Bronstein is an illustrator and designer living in Brooklyn. He graduated from RISD in 2009 with a degree in illustration. He works in the advertising industry and works for a wide range of clientele, from exhibition design to editorial illustration. This is his first game.
Here's what our fans are saying about Side Effects...
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is our first game and if we don’t get the support we need from this Kickstarter, it could be our last. That would be beyond tragic, and not just because of all of the hours upon hours of work we’ve put into this over the past year, but because people love playing this game.

We've done the leg work. We've worked with various producers to make sure our cards are high quality and up to our standards. If all goes well (fingers crossed) we can continue to provide you games with the same level of enjoyment, quality, and humor as Side Effects.

Shipping and fulfillment is the most stressful and highest risk part of this campaign. We have decided to focus on our efforts in delivering in North America and Europe in the most affordable way possible. Unfortunately for those outside of these countries, the shipping may be very expensive. We'll be doing our best, but do reach out with questions, we're happy to look up shipping for your address before you purchase.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Note on shipping: we've outlined the shipping costs for select countries, but if you don't live in these countries then you can pay the listed price and we will contact you after the campaign for an exact amount. If you have any questions, please contact us shiphappens@pillboxgames.com

support.title: POLYMANIA
support.descp:
Buy 3 games, save 5 bucks!
Includes:
- 90 cards x 3
- 2-piece box x 3
- 1 rulebook x 3
Note on shipping: we've outlined the shipping costs for select countries, but if you don't live in these countries then you can pay the listed price and we will contact you after the campaign for an exact amount. If you have any questions, please contact us shiphappens@pillboxgames.com

support.title: LIGNUMANIA
support.descp:
A handcrafted wooden box decked out in original artwork, 1 travel-sized linen pouch, and 1 copy Side Effects (includes 2-piece box, rulebook, and 90 cards).
Only ships to the United States. These wooden boxes are made in America and shipping to outside the US is very costly. If you have any questions, please contact us at shiphappens@pillboxgames.com

support.title: MEGALOMANIA
support.descp:
The ultimate package. Each limited-edition wooden box is handcrafted and fits 1 deck perfectly. In addition to 2 copies of Side Effects (each with their own boxes and rulebooks), you'll receive a letterpress print signed by our illustrious illustrator, and a travel pouch for Side Effects on the go.
Only ships to the United States. These wooden boxes are made in America and shipping to outside the US is very costly. If you have any questions, please contact us at shiphappens@pillboxgames.com

updates.update_userinfo: The Successor of Side Effects is ALIVE!
updates.update_content: I know I know I KNOW! I said I wasn't going to write in here anymore, but we have a big announcement and we need to get everyone's attention.

Wow. Our 36th update. I honestly didn’t think there was a number greater than 32!
But, much like a möbius strip, all things must come to an end.
Thanks for sticking around all this time, listening to us blab on and on about Side Effects. I mean, enough is enough already, am I right? But maybe I’m not right. Maybe, this end is only the beginning.

updates.update_userinfo: The End is Weds. Also, Gifs-count Codes!
updates.update_content:
Closin' Up the Shop this Weds
This Wednesday, December 5 is the last day to buy Side Effects. We're not making any more of these beautiful little weirdos, so don't miss out. 
 Click this ----> BUY SIDE EFFECTS

Guess what?? Our flash sale is killin' it! The games are selling like hot cakes (do those even exist anymore?) and...
We’re now shipping games to Mexico, Japan, Canada, most of Europe, China, and more!
Shipping rates vary depending on the country. Shipping to certain countries may not guarantee delivery by December 25.
First off, numbies, we cannot thank you enough for all the kind words about the game. We’re loving all the pictures and videos from all over the world. Keep ‘em coming!

Ahoy there, numbskulls!
As some of you may have noticed in the comments section and on social media (#pillboxgames), games are arriving! Most of Europe and Asia have received their games and now North America should expect an influx. We’ve also just received word that the games arrived in Australia and are going through customs! Any day now, you will receive Side Effects!

Yes, it’s Update 30! And we’ve got some exciting, adult-centric news for y’all.
Land Ho!
The games are on the ground and Quartermasters is beginning the picking process in the UK (printing labels, organizing the games by location, etc). As for the US, we’ve been told that the warehouse was a little backed up, but that they should be able to complete the picking process by Monday.
It’s the final countdown!

updates.update_userinfo: Make Sure Your Address Is Up to Date
updates.update_content:
Greetings, numbskulls!
Welcome to Update 28. We personally guarantee this to be the twenty-eightiest update of them all!!!

New side effects can be placed beside the others in your psyche (keeping in mind you can only have each disorder once, treated or not) but you should not be stacking anything beyond the disorder and the drug to treat it with. Therapy cards remove 1 disorder only.
Got it- we were putting them on top rather than to the side, splayed so you could see what was below, but definitely easier to put them to the side.
And to make sure I understand the Therapy card- when you use it on an illness that has one or more side effects on it, the therapy just gets rid of the top malady, not the whole stack, correct?

A drug card goes on top of a disorder, but the drug card has potential side effects, which one can place on top of the drug card, making a new top disorder card...which can then be treated with a drug card, no? Or if you treat it with a therapy card, only the newer side effect psychosis gets removed, or the whole stack, i.e.: original malady/drug card/side effect malady?

The GIF was confusing because it showed the other player giving the first player another psychosis immediately after she had treated it with therapy- which looked out of turn- so is that to show you don’t have to wait for your turn to give another player a psychosis? You can just do them whenever/in another person's turn?

On the matter of the six card limit in the hand- if you had six cards already at the beginning of your turn, could you still draw two cards from the deck and then discard two immediately before playing anything, throw out two cards *before* drawing two from the deck, or not draw any cards at all but just play cards already in your hand?

@Ole The pledge manager typically doesn't launch until at least 2 weeks after the project funds. This basic delay is because it takes two weeks for kickstarter to collect the funds and get them to the creator so that they can, in turn, apply those funds to the pledge manager. Any delay beyond that is usually because the creator is making a more advanced pledge manager system which likely isn't really needed in this case. With the two week funding period happening so near the holidays, I would expect that there will be some natural delays due to the various companies celebrating the holiday. My guess is we'll see the pledge manager after Jan 1.
