campaign.story:
We printers put ink on paper. Lots of ink. A great deal of that ink we mix ourselves. So we know that mixing & matching color is critical to a good printing. I print everyday. And I wrestled with color matching problems routinely—until I built a tool that solves many of these problems, the Ink Dial™.
The Ink Dial cleanly and precisely dispenses any amount of ink, without weighing, “eyeballing” or guesswork. It allows color mixes to be accurately repeated, thus reducing waste, time & money. It's not just a tool but a simple color mixing system that allows more control over this essential part of printing.
Based on my success with the Ink Dial in my own studio, I want to get it out into the world. Since it is so easy to use, it will prove incredibly useful to the teaching & practice of printmaking & letterpress printing, handy in the classroom, the artist’s studio, and to beginning & experienced printers alike practicing these disappearing crafts.
The Rewards & the Artists
As a letterpress printer, I particularly enjoy printing the work of lettering artists. It is challenging work and they are often the most demanding, yet interesting clients. 
So with two simple notions in mind (lettering & color) I approached 15 internationally known artists whose work involves lettering in some form or fashion for help with the rewards portion of this project.
Based solely on my detailed description of The Ink Dial, the artists offered me original work to print letterpress in a limited edition, each print signed by the artist. Many of the designs will be created solely for this project (see Updates for examples), and printed using The Ink Dial’s mixing system. The artists are:
Marian Bantjes
Alan Blackman
Andrew Byrom
Michael Clark
Michael Doret
Ed Fella
Eric Hanson
Carl Kurtz
Carl Rohrs
Yvette Rutledge
Paul Shaw
Susan Skarsgård
John Stevens
Sumner Stone
Jack Unruh
A very diverse & eclectic mix, to say the least. Their faith in this project is heartening. I hope you will join them in supporting this project!
What’s the goal of your Kickstarter campaign?
The goal of my Kickstarter campaign is to manufacture a dozen sets of Ink Dials and install them in a diversity of print shop environments so the system may be  put through its paces, leading toward the Ink Dial’s commercial availability. This latest round of products will include many new features improving upon my rough working prototype system.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Progress? I wish I could say everything is coming along on a nice, timely schedule, but I can’t. However, what I can say is that everything is coming along very well as far as the quality of the Ink Dial and the prints are concerned.
First, the tool itself. This is the gauntlet I’ve been through these last several months: I’d go to a fabricator and they tell me they “get it.” Then monies were paid, weeks went by and I’d get back something they’d “interpreted.” I’ve gone through a number of prototypes and fabricators. I’ve settled on using a great guy now because he’s sharp, he’s local and his craftsmanship is top notch. And by far he’s come closest to hitting the nail on the head as far as building the exact design I am after.

Dear Ink Dial backers
I apologize over-extending your patience; this update is long overdue. Such correspondence has fallen victim to a myopic focus on building the tool, which is taking much more time than I expected.
The magnitude of such big projects in general is difficult to gauge. The famous computer scientist Donald Knuth once advised converting one's prediction to the next higher measure of time, e.g. one week becomes one month, etc. and then multiplying by some number, usually at least three. Computing algorithms would be a welcome activity at this point compared to finding & dealing with good fabricators—like herding cats almost.

There are just a handful of puzzle pieces that prompted me to undertake this endeavor and to offer these print rewards. There's a story to tell about where I sit at the dinner table and a Reynolds Stone alphabet staring all day long at a Susan Skarsgard alphabet on the wall opposite. 
Another story is about a gift I received from my printing hero Harold McGrath. It was a large print of an alphabet of gothic letterforms with each letter printed in a different color. At least 26 different colors on that press sheet. As always, his work left me wondering "How'd the hell he do that?" A question like that stuck in my mind and as a result over time the Ink Dial was concocted. But that colorful alphabet was etched deep into my memory and so became natural point of departure when I cooked up these rewards.

I appreciate every ounce of support shown me over the last two months and then some. I couldn't have gotten this far without you all.

Once the unsuccessful campaign ends I believe I am restricted from using this platform. But I'd just like to express my heart-felt thanks once again and ask you all to stay tuned to inkdial.com. We'll see together what good things are in store for us in the days, weeks & months ahead.

Be well my friends.

Granted this piece is only tentatively titled, but do you know what I like best about Eric Hanson's work? As quick and as expressive as they may seem, they are always built solid state from the sharpest of ideas. I can't claim to know the man well but his work always transfixes me. I'd be more than happy printing his work the rest of my days.

updates.update_userinfo: the old end and a new beginning
updates.update_content:
This just in! Carl Kurtz' sublime "Cascade." 
Composed of two words, one evolving into the other: meretricious (at the top) & ornamentation (at the bottom), these words can be read in the piece. "Albeit with some difficulty" cites the artist. "This piece comes out of a group of work that deals with self-delusion and narcissism, particularly in the arts where high sounding words with little meaning are used to impress people. This personal bombast is commonplace. And yes, in its own way, this image/drawing is self-deprecating."

campaign.story:
WE DID IT!  Thank you to everyone who backed TOAST and helped spread the word.  Toast was a success because of you!
If you came to this page after fundraising has ended, please visit www.toastmade.com to place orders.
Thank you so much!  Matias
CUSTOM WOOD VENEERS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE YOUR IPHONE
With real wood veneers from Toast you can add both grip and protection to the iPhone 4 and 4S without adding to the phone’s size or covering up the elegant design.  The texture of the wood grain makes it much less slippery and you can toss your iPhone on a table without worrying about scratching the back glass.
And, just as importantly, the veneer enhances the look of the iPhone by adding warm natural materials and allowing you to personalize your phone.  Who wants their iPhone to look exactly like the other 50 million of them out there?
By combining computer controlled laser cutting, high quality veneers and hand finishing, Toast brings style, protection and customization to you at a very affordable price. 
The best way to support Toast is to pre-order your custom veneer.  Pledges of $20 and up are essentially pre-orders of custom veneers at a special Kickstarter-only price (saving you at least $5 off the retail price).  You can choose from two different woods, either a rich, chocolaty walnut or a whitewashed, quarter-cut ash.  
Keep it simple or add one of eight cool etched designs, some of which feature cutouts that let the silver of the apple logo show through.
Then personalize your veneer further by adding custom text that will be laser etched into the wood.  Add your name or contact information, or perhaps a favorite quote or poem.
All pre-orders also get the option of including an exclusive Kickstarter Sponsor logo etched into your veneer, so you can flaunt the fact that you were part of making Toast possible.
If you like this project but don't have an iPhone, you can still support us.  For a $5 pledge you will receive two wood stickers, etched with the Toast and Kickstarter Sponsor logos.
Toast veneers fit perfectly with the Apple bumper.
Shipping is free in the USA.  International shipping cost is $5 to any country outside the USA.  International backers please add $5 to your pledge to cover shipping.
Please help us spread the word and make sure we get funded!
www.facebook.com/toastmade
Our Twitter feed is @Toastmade.
Follow us on Instagram: Toastmade
You can also find more information on toast’s website www.toastmade.com
Thank you so much for your support!
Matias

updates.update_content:
Wow! One year has flown by since all of you helped me launch Toast. I cannot begin to say how grateful I am to all of you for your amazing support. Not only did you get great covers for your iPhones, but you launched a successful small business. 
For one year now we have been continuing to create new exciting products, good local jobs and make a positive impact in the world. One year ago Toast was an idea and, with your help, the seed money to get a laser and start production. Toast now has 5 employees, a nice rented studio/ production building and an expanding product line. I have brought the same materials and design sensibilities to covers for the iPad, iPad mini, iPhone 5 and Samsung Galaxy S3. We also just launch gorgeous wood wraps for the sides of the iPhone that add more protection, grip and a whole lot more style.

Team Toast is back and working hard to get you your rewards.  On Saturday we shipped about 20 boxes and today we shipped about 40 more to Kickstarter backers!  Most of the US rewards have been shipped and we will start shipping the International ones tomorrow.  (This wasn’t a US bias, all the custom forms, labels, etc needed for international shipping have been tricky to figure out.)  A few International backers still need to send us your phone number.  If you haven’t emailed us your phone number, please send it to cs@toastmade.com.  We can’t ship to you outside of the USA without a phone number.

The good news is that our laser is up and running.  Yesterday I cut the first batch of Kickstarter rewards!  We plan to ship about half the rewards tomorrow. 
The bad news is that we are having some problems with the laser that limits the designs I can cut right now.  I need to get a new controller card and this will take a couple weeks before it is installed and up and running.  This only effects a few of the less popular designs.  So if you ordered the plain, apple cutout, skull and crossbones or bird on a branch designs, these we are cutting now.

Hello Backers!
We have been working hard to get Toast up and running and have made a lot of progress in the last two weeks.  We received our laser cutter!  It is installed in the shop and I hope to have it all dialed in this week.  Next week we will be cutting your Toast rewards!
I am also proud to announce that Toast is now member #2730 of 1% For The Planet and will be donating 1% of our sales to non-profit groups working to make a healthy planet.

Hello backers! 
I just wanted to give you an update on Toast.  It has been an exciting couple of weeks since we successfully funded our Kickstarter project. 
Most of you have completed your backer survey.  If you didn’t receive one, check your spam folder and if you still can’t find it, contact the Kickstarter help desk by hitting the contact link on the bottom of any Kickstarter web page.

Hello Backers,
I have had a few requests for a photo of the the different text sizes to help you choose  for the custom text on your covers.  Here are the three sizes available 6 pt, 8 pt and 10 pt in the Arial Bold font.
Hope this helps.  If you feel that you want to change your text size that you already specified in the backer survey, email me with the change and include the pledge amount you gave to help me find your file and make the changes.

Thank you, thank you, thank you for all you did to help make Toast a reality.  I was blown away by how excited you are about Toast.  The energy and enthusiasm you showed helped propel me through when it looked like we didn’t have a chance of making our funding goal.  It was a real pleasure getting to know many of you.  And I want you to know that this is just the beginning.  You played a critical role in helping to create a wonderful new business that will continue to make elegant, creative products that enrich our lives.

campaign.story:
Lead Graffiti is a letterpress studio in Newark, Delaware. We like spontaneous projects, the Tour de France, and excuses to put ink on paper.
Pitting our print race against their bike race, we intend to produce a minimum of 25 portfolios of 23 posters (about 15" x 22") via letterpress, one for each stage of the upcoming Tour de France (Saturday, July 2 through Sunday, July 24) plus its two rest days (they can rest, but we won't).
After watching the Tour live on TV each morning (8:30 am - 12:30 pm), we'll choose an incident or moment that made an impact on that day's stage or perhaps one that offers a great visual interpretation. This element will be visually represented through wood & metal type, linoleum cuts, and printing from cycling-related objects. A poster visually documenting each day's stage will be printed the same day at Lead Graffiti.
Additionally, we will produce a title page, a colophon, and a page with descriptions of each poster. These series will be enclosed in a handmade portfolio covered with Lead Graffiti pastepaper.
Kickstarter supporters of our Tour de Lead Graffiti project will receive their rewards at a discounted price from what they will be sold for after the project ends. The posters will be numbered in sequence with Kickstarter supporters getting the lowest available numbers and first choice of individual posters set aside for this purpose.
Money received through Kickstarter is intended to help fund the material costs of the project, including the purchase of Somerset paper, portfolio raw materials, and two new wood type faces being made specifically for this project. We also expect to provide at least a few keepsakes in the form of wood type actually used to print the posters to accompany each complete portfolio.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
The first rewards which included posters and full portfolios started going out yesterday, September 9. Start looking for it in a few days.
The rest should go out today or Monday.

We hope everyone is keeping up with our progress on the Tour de Lead Graffiti project. We have nine stages and the first rest day (for the Tour de France) behind us. We printed yesterday. The printing has been going great and has been wonderful fun.
When we started this we were wondering how "endurance letterpress" would feel. The number of hours Ray alone put in on the project the first week was 107 hours. ONE WEEK.

Well, we've got less than 9 hours until the live TV feed of the Tour de France on Versus starts.
We went to the Truck Stop just outside of Newark, Delaware tonite. Ray carboloaded with spaghetti. Should we wear our cycling gear to the studio tomorrow?
We got our new wood type (see "colophon" below for one of them) all cleaned up and soaked in linseed oil so that should be ready to go. We got the imprint in the lower left corner (also see that below) showing the date, stage number, from-to, kilometers and a Lead Graffiti logo and our ever present words, "Printed slowly & patiently via letterpress in Newark, Delaware" on all 23 posters. We even started the colophon page by printing 'colophon' in the middle with our new 12 line Clarendon Heavy. For any non-letterpress printers out there that means the type is 2" high.

We are so excited to be doing this project. Thanks to everyone from the largest to the smallest pledge for connecting with us.
We ordered the paper yesterday. 700 sheets (we get two posters per sheet) of Somerset Textured White. We even decided to go with the heavier 300 g/sm option. It is really a wonderful paper.
We're currently watching the Tour de Suisse each evening as some pre-Tour training. That is a nine-day race that ends this coming Sunday.

comments.content: I must say that not only are the posters amazing as stand-alone pieces, but as a full set in hand-made clamshell, they are just awe inspiring. WOW!

Congratulations to the Lead Graffiti team on the success of the Endurance Letterpress endeavor, and may this inspire others to tackle similar projects. (Or maybe Lead Graffiti will consider this again?) It was such a pleasure to check in every day to see what went on the day before, and your project added immeasurably to my enjoyment of the race. Thanks to all.
http://leadgraffiti.com/news/tour-de-lead-graffiti/main.asp

Printed Stage 3 yesterday with Ray and Jill (and my daughter Lucie). What a memorable 4th of July. Fun to look for "the moment" in le Tour and to bring it forth with Team Lead Graffiti. This is a great project.

This is truly an inspired idea for a Kickstarter project. Only Ray has the incredible energy, creativity, and drive to pull off something this ambitious. Twenty three posters, one every day for 23 days, even the cyclists on the Tour get two days of rest! Don't miss the chance to be part of this, it is Letterpress Printing at it's best.
Donation made in Honor of Cuz Howies continued good health!
Pelaton! Pelaton!

campaign.story:
The GoPano micro is a lens for the iPhone 4 to make 360º panoramic videos! Just snap the lens to your iPhone 4 and press record to make cool interactive 360º videos. Use it to record all the action of your favorite sport, record your next meeting in 360º or just as a fun toy for the summer.
The GoPano micro will record everything around you simultaneously. You can go back to the recorded video and choose to view any perspective, any angle at any point in time. The GoPano app allows you to upload your 360º video onto our web platform and share 360º videos with your friends. You can watch 360º videos uploaded by others in the app or on the web site. (the GoPano lens records everything simultaneously and not just the scene on the screen, you can pan & zoom in/out anywhere in your recorded video).
Our Goal
Imagine watching a football game broadcast and being able to follow your favorite player all the time. Imagine a bride being able to "turn around" in her wedding video and see her parents' faces the moment the officiant says, "I now pronounce you husband and wife"!
GoPano's technology brings a new angle to making videos. By freeing the video from the single perspective of a conventional camera, you can interact with the video in a way never before possible. We strongly believe that 360º video will become as important in broadcasting as sound was to silent movies or color television was to black & white.
While we've offered 360º video products for years to professionals, GoPano micro is our first step in making panoramic video technology accessible to the masses.
With Your Help.
We want your help to make GoPano micro a reality. We have a working prototype and the essential software ready. A web platform to host 360º interactive movies is on its way. We are requesting your support to make this product a commercial reality. Support us on Kickstarter, tell your friends and spread this idea. And yes, you don't have to stick to the tiers, please feel free to contribute any amount. 
We are very thrilled with this new project. We hope with your support we can make this technology- The technology of the future!
* Today, the GoPano micro optic is compatible with the iPhone 4 only. With the success of this project, we will broaden this technology to include more smart phones, mobile devices and cameras.
** An example of a 360 interactive video shot with a GoPano Plus optic

updates.update_content:
After a torrent of interest, months of hard work and perseverance we are very pleased to have delivered GoPano micro to all of our backers and thousands more since. You can pick up your own GoPano micro at store.gopano.com, or from one of our growing list of resellers, including Amazon.com, Adorama, B&H Photo, BiteMyApple.co, ThinkGeek and many more to come.
GoPano micro is not just an optical device, but also an iPhone app and a hosting web site. In the past few months, we've created a mass-produced panoramic optic device, with a brand new mirror design that's never existed before. We've developed software to unwarp, present and record video from this device in real time, on a computer that fits in your pocket. We've made the first ever video hosting site specifically geared towards panoramic video, and we're providing it for free to all of our users. All three are tied together so you can create, publish, and explore panoramic video content from around the world in the palm of your hand. We've put this all together in about 6 months, with an engineering team that's small enough to share a table at lunch, while continuing to support our existing products.

updates.update_userinfo: GoPano 1.0 is now available with full iPhone 4S support!!!
updates.update_content:
GoPano 1.0 App is live, download your free app here - goo.gl/4O8qc
- Upload your videos directly from your iPhone to gopano.com. - Automatic calibration of lens. - Full iPhone 4S support. - New look. - And more.

Hi again,
We were able to get our hands on an iPhone 4S today and we have good news for everyone - the GoPano micro is compatible. We made a few minor changes to the 1.0 app to adjust for the iPhone 4S and we will be submitting it to Apple for review today. As for the case, it fits without any issues.

Hi All,
We're anxiously awaiting our new iPhone tomorrow. We will report on compatibility once we have one in-hand. There's a pretty good chance that the GoPano micro optic will work as-is.
For those of you who get your iPhone 4S: Please note that the GoPano 0.9 app will not show recording controls on the new phone just yet. This is because we were testing specifically for iPhone 4 models to enable the recorder, not because there is any known compatibility issue. The GoPano 1.0 app will enable recording with the 4S and will be available in the App Store once it passes through Apple's approval process.

updates.update_userinfo: All GoPano micros have been shipped!!!
updates.update_content:
The last couple of days have been busy ones here at EyeSee360, but we have finished shipping the last of the GoPano micros to the backers - over 1000 units in the last 24 hours! We want to thank all of you for your help with this project. Everyone here on the GoPano team hopes that you will enjoy your product as much as we do.

A few backers have shipment address issues. Our staff will be in touch to resolve these issues as soon as possible.

updates.update_userinfo: A Couple of Notes About Shipping
updates.update_content: After almost ten months of development, the EyeSee360 web team is proud to announce the launch of the first 360 degree video sharing site, GoPano.com. We hope that you'll enjoy using the site as much as we've enjoyed making it. GoPano.com is designed to be a space to view panoramic videos and share them with the world. We've focused on making the site immersive and streamlined; users can easily upload, embed, and discuss videos.

updates.update_userinfo: Tutorial Video for GoPano 0.9 app and upcoming features in the GoPano 1.0 app
updates.update_content: 700 more GoPano micros are shipping from our office today. Our shipments are going out first to backers outside the US, country by country. We're working as fast as we can to fulfill all orders. Starting next week we'll be sending out U.S. orders. We're averaging 300 units per day from manufacturing, which is not as high as we'd like but the rate is improving. We will be down for two days for maintenance before we get back to production.

There has been endless rumor and speculation about the next iPhone. Apple has not released any official information about a new version of the iPhone, so unfortunately features, size and other changes are just that, speculation. Today, we have no actionable information to go on to say if today's GoPano micro is compatible, nor to work on a new version that would be.
There is justifiable concern about GoPano micro compatibility with a new iPhone, and the simple answer is we don't know any more about it today than we did 4 months ago. However, since many expect a new model announcement within weeks, we have a contingency plan to support our Kickstarter backers for what may come.

campaign.story:
Missed out on the Kickstarter campaign? No worries, head to http://studioneat.com/cosmo/ to sign up to be notified when the Cosmonaut becomes available for sale. You can also follow us on twitter (@studioneat) to receive project updates. Thanks!
Hello friends! Thanks for visiting our Kickstarter page for the Cosmonaut, a minimal, wide-grip capacitive stylus for touch screen devices.
The Cosmonaut was born out of our desire to have a really great stylus for our iPads. We love to sketch out quick ideas or doodle on our tablets, and using a stylus is much better than a finger for such tasks. We bought several different models currently available on the market but they all suffered the same problem: they were designed to look and feel like a pen. But why? Writing or drawing on the iPad feels nothing like using a pen or pencil. For one, tablets are ideal for low fidelity sketching. Also, it is pretty awkward to rest your palm on the screen of the device because it throws off the capacitive detection. Writing on a tablet feels like writing on a dry erase board: fast, simple, low fidelity. The perfect tablet stylus is one that feels like a dry erase marker.
Dan created a blog post about this very idea right after our first Kickstarter campaign ended, and quite a few people seemed to be keen on it, so we decided to start designing a solution. After immersing ourselves in research, prototyping, and design iteration, we’ve arrived at something that we think is pretty great. It’s comfortable to hold and effortlessly glides over the glass surface of the tablet. It just feels right.
In returning to Kickstarter for our second project, we wanted to try something different. You may notice that there is only one pricing tier to the right, for $1. That is not a mistake. Inspired by Radiohead, we wanted to try out a pay-as-you-wish pricing model. Pledge whatever value you feel the Cosmonaut is worth to you. A few things to keep in mind:
There are only 3000 pledging slots available. So, if everyone only pledges $1, the funding goal of $50,000 will obviously not be met.
The funding goal of $50,000 was arrived at after getting quotes from our manufacturer (in the USA).
If we meet our funding goal (which would be awesome!) it means we will be able to sell the Cosmonaut in our online store later on. We are thinking it will retail for $25. Perhaps this price can be used as a guide for your own contribution.
Get them while they’re hot! Once the 3000 slots run out, you won’t be able to get a Cosmonaut until they become available in our online store. Consider it a limited edition run to test the feasibility of a full scale run.
Based on the timetable our manufacturer gave us, we should begin shipping the Cosmonauts in June.
There are two prototypes featured in the video above: a "look and feel" prototype and a functional prototype. We are continuing to refine / improve the design (including the tip) but the final design will have that same form and spirit of the prototypes.
The Cosmonaut is compatible with any capacitive touch screen device. Eg. iPad, iPhone, iPod Touch, Samsung Galaxy Tab, Motorola Xoom, etc.
This is the first we are aware of a pay-as-you-wish pricing model for a physical, tangible product. We are interested to see how it turns out!
Once again, we can’t thank you all enough for your continued support. You are allowing us to continue to do what we love. As always, the Cosmonaut is the labor of love of two individuals, Tom Gerhardt and Dan Provost. We are the two dudes who brought you the Glif just 4 months ago, and are looking forward to another project!

Risks and challenges

updates.update_content:
Hello Comrades,
Happy New Year! Hope you all had (or are having) a lovely break for the holidays. We wanted to give a quick update on the status of everything. 
The majority of you should have received your Cosmonaut by now, or at the very least received a shipping confirmation that it is on its way. If neither of these is true, it likely means you never filled in the address survey. If you never received the Cosmonaut or even a shipping notice, sent us a message and we'll track down the problem and get it straightened out. If you are overseas and haven't received it yet, sit tight, there are quite a few still in transit we imagine.

Hello Comrades,

Just a brief update. About 1200 Cosmonauts arrived today to our US warehouses, and we are going to be sending batches of 1200 or so each day this week to our warehouses in LA, Philly, and the UK. In other words, some backers will begin receiving Cosmonauts by the end of this week, and they will continue to be rolled out into the next week. Exciting!

Hello Comrades!

Well, the day is upon us. We both just got back from a week long trip to South Dakota, where we evaluated the tip and overmold production, and made sure everything was moving along as it should be. We have in our hands a final, completed Cosmonaut, and it is awesome. We can't wait to show it to you all. It's been a long journey, but we think the wait will be worth it.

Hello Comrades,

We just wanted to remind everyone who has not filled out the survey yet, please do so. The vast majority of you already have (thank you!) but there are still a few stragglers. We are going to set a hard deadline for this Friday to fill it out. If you don't fill it in by then, it doesn't mean you won't get a Cosmonaut, it just means you won't be in the first batch that gets shipped out. So please fill it out ASAP!

Hello Comrades,

Just a quick note, we have now sent the surveys out to all of our backers. You should have gotten an email from Kickstarter with a link to the survey. If not, head to Kickstarter.com and login, there should be a banner at the top of the page directing you to the survey. 

Please fill it out as soon as you can, this is the ONLY way we can obtain your shipping address. Also, this is how you let us know if you want an aluminum or wood end cap.

Hello Comrades,

We wanted to give a quick update on our timeline, now that things are getting locked down for production and delivery. 

As we said in our last update, we hope to have these sent to the warehouses ready to ship out by the end of November, and everything is still in order to meet that timetable (knock on wood). Here is the status of all the components:

Hello Comrades,
Some exciting (non Cosmonaut related) news, Dan got married last weekend! Tom was a groomsmen, and a good time was had by all. 
Anyhow, even with all of that excitement, we haven't been sitting still with the Cosmonaut. In fact, we've made some fairly big design changes. Mind you, these changes will not really affect the outward appearance, but rather, how the Cosmonaut is manufactured. We want to take some time now to explain the process in detail of how this is being made, for those interested. If you have no interest in these kinds of details, feel free to skip to the end.

Hello Comrades,
We received the preproduction samples in the mail this weekend, and they are looking pretty snazzy! Check out the glamour shots below.
They look and feel great, but functionally are not quite there yet. The amount of friction is acceptable, but you have to press a little too hard for the stylus to register on the screen. So, we have some knobs to turn to fix this problem, and we are working closely with the manufacturing to evaluate our options. Stay tuned. We are still on track for an Autumn delivery, and will have a better idea of a more specific timetable once we are ready to roll in to full production.

Hello Comrades, 
We finally have some good news to report! Our long struggle with finding the right material is over, and we are receiving pre-production samples of the Cosmonaut in about two weeks. This is essentially the last stage where we make sure everything looks and feels as expected before we pull the trigger on full scale production. We will post an update at that time to show off what you will ultimately be receiving!

Hello Comrades,
We just wanted to pop up to say hello. We have been quite busy searching for the right materials, and are working hard to prepare the design for manufacturing. We don't have much new to physically show, but check out the attached image of some of the materials and prototypes we have been testing and evaluating.

I was a little concerned with the talk that some people have had to press hard to get it to register - I've had no such problems with my iPad 2. I was prepared to have to press a little bit to get it to work but to my surprise, it glides across the screen effortlessly and smoothly! If you're having to press down hard to get it to register, based on my own quick experience with the Cosmonaut, it has to be a faulty tip. In Penultimate, when I just barely touch the screen with my Cosmonaut, it registers 98% I write or draw. When I just give it a ever-so-slightly firmer touch, it registers everything. Everything I was hoping it would be. Thanks guys!

Thanks and keep up the good work.

I can't wait to get my Cosmonaut!

Nick

My tip appears to work as its supposed to -- It's not at all the tip I pledged money to back the development of (what the fuck is it with the enormous tips every damn stylus has? I liked that the original prototype had a smaller, more focused point of contact) but my real gripe is the material used for the stylus itself. I suppose it feels nice in the hand, but it's so prone to picking up dust and lint from the air that it looked filthy when I took it out of the box. I guess I'll just keep looking, or learn how to make my own.

I don't know if it was just a bad batch or there is some inconsistency in the manufacturing process, but the difference between the original tip and this new one is night and day. I can write, draw, and quickly tap with it and the Cosmonaut is performing like it should. I would definitely recommend this now with the new tip.

Thanks Nik. The stylus is unless to me the way it currently performs, so I've got nothing to lose. Three days and no email reply back from Studio Neat. Such a shame. I love how this feels in the hand.

@happyguy mine was just held on by force. check this site for the construction diagram. the internal aluminum tip is like a stair-stepped cone with tapered steps. the steps are acting like barbs, passively holding on the tip cover. just get your fingernail under the seam and pull it out at right angles to the shaft. when it deforms enough it will just slip off. cheers.
How do you remove the tip without damaging it? I've tried and tried and it seems glued on!

TIP: for anyone who doesn't like the squishy tip feel. Remove the tip and put a small piece of paper tissue (or TP) in the end of the cap and a drop of water. When you place the cap back on the tip feels a lot more solid and seems to register with less pressure. It's a total hack, but it works for me. Trying to be constructive. :-)

VERY DISAPPOINTED. After waiting for so long, I am disappointed, like many others, in the pressure required to register that I'm drawing. The air pocket also lends a weird feel to it. I thought I had finally found a stylus for sketching, but I guess not. The homemade stylus I made from an old pen barrel and piece of Scotchbrite sponge works much better than this. *sigh*

Ilike how the Cosmonaut feels, but I don't like that I have to put so much pressure on it. I bought the pen also for my kids but they don't use it anymore because of this. Ithink it isn't worth the 25 bucks. Maybe a replacemnet tip could solve the problems but I don't know how to get that.

I am a very very happy lady.

I've just got the stylus today and i'm deeply disappointed with the result of this stylus. This is all you've got for wasting my 6 months waiting. The pressure needed to make this works is just unbelievably annoying and the stylus is also not sensitive at all. I've bought another $25 stylus from Faraday and it works just like my finger, smooth, soft, sensitive and widely available. This is just another disaster. Ok ... I feel bad about my comments 2 down ... For anyone struggling, try cleaning your screen ...mine was by no means filthy, but degreasing it has made a BIG improvement. Having played a bit more, I fear for the lifespan of the tip ... the pressure needed to get satisfactory registration on my iPad bends the tip way out of shape. Something else I've noticed is that the registration improves if I use the cosmonaut at 90 degrees to the touchscreen ... which feels unnatural but is much more effective.

Such a shame about the tip failing so badly. Really nice product but fatally flawed ... mine too will be passed on as a Christmas present. It would be interesting to know what discussions took place around the tip design & why needing such pressure to register made it's way into the final design ... OR ... are some people getting defective ones & others getting the beautiful effortless gliding stylus that we all got so excited about?

The debate I'm seeing here is a little odd. The project sponsors asked us to pledge (assuming we want the stylus) what we (1) thought it was worth to us plus (2) our best guess at what shipping it would be. If the project sponsors are OK with the first 3000 backers getting the reward, and playing prisoner's dilemma with the rest of their sponsors, why should we get pissy? The sponsors who are backing at the $12 level are doing what they were told to do (for what it is worth, I think it is worth $15 bucks to me, and that it should cost about $3 to ship by US Post, and so pledged accordingly). The limit on the reward clearly exists so that the project developers can make sure that they don't have to ship 50000 styli out on a 50000 budget. Correct me if I'm wrong, but people can still donate to the project after the 3000 rewards are used up, and in the meantime, hopefully the donors are getting some useful information about their proposed price point (though I doubt that, this seems like a fairly stupid way to conduct market research).

campaign.story:
"A written word is the choicest of relics." -Thoreau
For 75 years, Vandercook printing presses were manufactured right here in my beloved Chicago. Of the 38,000 presses that were made, very few exist in operable condition. The lucky ones have been forgotten in barns, basements and backrooms. Countless others were carted off by scrap metal collectors and destroyed.
They are large and heavy machines, and they are beautiful. Each press has a personality and quirks, which is why they are often given a name. My objective is to purchase a Vandercook press and set it up in a functional studio here in Chicago. It will be restored and fully operational so that it can be used for many years to come. I plan to set up shop in the historic Pilsen neighborhood and have found a great studio space in an old warehouse by the Chicago River.
The studio will be named Pilsenette Press and will be available for use by members. Their rental fees will help maintain the press and cover the costs of rent and supplies. There are very few facilities in Chicago that offer letterpress instruction and rental to artists. I want to promote the art by making it accessible. Furthermore, I want to provide beginning artists with a place to print their own art.
This is where we need you! The press will need to be moved by professionals familiar with heavy equipment. I have identified a shared studio space where the press can be operated and stored. Your backing helps move the press, set it up and purchase essential printing supplies like quoins, a Boxcar base and inks. I have located a press for sale and it will be $7500 delivered.
I fell in love when I made my first print and I want to share that with others. It is my hope that local students can come to the studio and learn about printing. I want them to understand the detail and skill that went into printing books of the past. I currently have three artists lined up to work together in this studio, creating greeting cards, wedding and party invitations and art prints. A membership system will also be established to allow smaller-scale printers a venue to produce their art.
Thank you so much for checking out my project! If you have the ability to fund a few dollars, I am incredibly grateful. If not, you can help by sharing this with everyone you know!

campaign.story:
Here's the truth. We can't believe we wrote this. Really. I mean who gets up one day, brews a pot of coffee, and says, "Gee, I have a good idea. Why don't I think of all the embarrassing, awkward stories I have with the opposite sex, write them down, and then distribute them worldwide for everyone to point, laugh and leave in bathroom stalls?"
Well, apparently we do. And we need your help to embarrass ourselves.
In Fall 2011, we’ll be launching our new book Awkward Moments with Men: Stories About the Sex We Can't Live Without. It’s a coveted selection of humor essays that ventures into highly charted territory and documents the strange moments, unexpected fears, and over analysis that occurs when opposite sexes brush elbows and unmentionables.
All the stories are true, and all the men are anonymous. In a matter of 200 self-proclaimed pages of dazzling wit and humor, you can read about The Man Who Pees Sitting Down, the condom-swallowing dog, a highly unfortunate instance with a period and a guest bed, visiting a boyfriend in prison, and cancerous trips to the lady doctor, among others. The stories are honest and thoughtful and probably nothing you'll want to discuss with your grandmother. Get a glimpse of the contents here: http://awkwardmomentswithmen.tumblr.com/excerpts.
Equally as important as the contents is the way we're publishing. Rather than go the traditional route with lots of red tape and boring book signings that smell of unused sharpies, we’re going custom.
AWKWARD MOMENTS ART GALLERY To launch the book, we’ll be headed to ten cities (Atlanta, Austin, Boston, Chicago, Denver, Los Angeles, Nashville, New York, Seattle, and Toronto) where we’ll be partnering with local artists to create an innovative book launch. All participating artists will submit and exhibit one piece of visual art that centers on the theme ‘Awkward Moments with Men.’
On opening night, attendees will see the exhibit, vote on the piece they think best represents the theme, receive a free copy of the book, indulge in a little vino, and have an opportunity to share their own awkward moments in an interactive booth that they might or might not regret later. Ultimately the winning art pieces in each city will travel to the final gallery where they will stay on exhibit for a handful of months and continue to share awkward stories with the masses.
HOW YOUR INVESTMENT WILL HELP At minimum, we're looking at a $15,000 price tag to make this happen.Our goal is to do a major book release, which requires a quality product with quality exposure. Thankfully, we have the know-how, desire, and obscenely talented friends to pull this off. What we don't have is the large bank account of someone like our dear friend Mr. Harper Collins. Which is where you (and everyone you know) comes in.
Right now our $15,000 is breaking down as follows: * Editing ($1,000) * Cover Design/Typesetting ($2,000) * Printing and eBook Conversion ($7,000) * Creating an Interactive Website ($1,500) * Hiring a Publicist / Developing and Implementing a Creative Marketing Campaign ($2,500) * Making the Awkward Moments Art Gallery Tour a Reality ($1,000)
IF YOU CAN'T TELL, WE LOVE EVERYONE We know we're not famous. We know you could spend $100 getting hammered tonight or you could choose to spend it helping us. And we're prematurely going to thank you for picking one-night sobriety and awkwardness because we believe that A) you're a genuinely good person, and B) you'll be genuinely happy with your decision once you crack the spine of our awkward, if not a-little-too-close-to-home stories.
Please, please, please email us if you have any questions at all or simply want to say hi. We're all ears.
xo, blonde and brunette
AWKWARD ITEMS
Typography Mustache Mugs featured in the $30 Breakfast Package:

Dear friends. 
We finally got Awkward in the mail and -- after a massive packing party last week -- the books have been distributed to the four corners of the earth. Many of you have received them by now, but many of you are still holding your breath in anticipation. Don't worry. You will be rewarded shortly.

updates.update_userinfo: Your Awkward Address: An Update and Request
updates.update_content:
Dear friends.
We know we’ve been absent. But trust us, it’s for good reason. For the past few months, we’ve diligently mastered the craft of being authors. We’ve sat around a great deal, muttered heavily under our breath, and reorganized our sock drawer no less than seventy-three times. And somewhere in there – between the whites, the colors, and the whiskey – we scribbled out a whole tome of awkward stories for your reading enjoyment. We can now proudly and truthfully say that is at the printing press, being inked into a terrifying degree of permanency.

campaign.story:
A fun alternative to normal game dice!
I would like your help and support making a large production run of these dice and have them distributed as an educational item in university book stores.
These dice can be used as practical dice because they encorporate the standard face-values of 1-6, only in this case the numbers correlate to the elements: Hydrogen, Helium, Lithium, Beryllium, Boron and Carbon.
This would make a great gift for your chemestry friends!
As always with Kickstarter, If the funding goal is not reached (In this case, $2,500) your card will not be charged.
Thank you for your support!

updates.update_content: Hello everybody! I would like to thank you for your patience thus far. The manufacturing process of these dice have been a nightmare; ridden with delays, incorrect orders and miscommunication. The first shipment of dice I received were mis-colored (green with white ink), mis-counted (only received 200), and mis-printed(the element numbers were missing). I had to return them to the manufacturer for them to correct the order, which subsequently led to a drawn out argument that was only recently resolved. The company is now under new management and I was expecting the order to arrive today, but it looks like it will show up tomorrow or the next business day. I will make another update next week! Thank you for your support and patience! -Andrew

BIG NEWS!  You may purchase these dice at my website: www.inabasound.com   
Even if you've missed the project end-date, you may still order any quantity you like, paying securely through PayPal or using any major credit card.
Please note that there will be a $3 USD shipping charge regardless of the location or quantity ordered.  Since the item is still being manufactured, any processed orders will not be shipped till late April to early May.

campaign.story:
Experience the Art and Craft of Letterpress Printing on your iPad
LetterMpress™ will be a virtual letterpress environment—released first on the iPad—that will allow anyone to create authentic-looking letterpress designs and prints.
The design process is the same as the letterpress process—you place and arrange type and cuts on a press bed, lock the type, ink the type, and print. You will be able to create unlimited designs, with multiple colors, using authentic vintage wood type and art cuts. And you can print your design directly from LetterMpress or save it as an image for import it into other applications.
So why bother re-creating what’s considered to be an obsolete process for the new technology of the iPad?
Actually, a letterpress and an iPad operate similarly when it comes to manipulating objects in a composition. Just like placing blocks of wood type on a surface, you drag the type images across the iPad, and then move them around to create your design. This is why the iPad would make an ideal platform for people to experience the creative aspects of letterpress and typography.
A growing interest in letterpress—but difficult to access
In fact, letterpress has had a growing interest over the past decade amongst designers, artists, and printmakers. Call it a reaction to the “perfect” look of laser-printing. Letterpress—especially wood type—evokes a handcrafted appearance that accompanies thoughtful, visual, and literal expression.
But unfortunately, much of the letterpress’s traditional technology was sold for scrap metal and replaced with computers over the last 30 years. Wood type was burned, thrown in a landfill, or divided up as knick-knacks in antique and craft shops. The destruction of manual presses and thousands of type collections has made the tools of letterpress a scarce resource these days. What’s left of traditional letterpress machines, wood type, and printing paraphernalia now fetch premium collector prices because of the growing interest in this art. And complete sets of wood type are rare—bidding wars drive up the prices to several hundreds of dollars.
Our goal: Our goal is to give designers, artists, students, lovers of type—anyone—the ability to produce their own authentic letterpress designs and artwork. And that’s where this project starts and where we need your help!
Current feedback: We’ve shown our prototype to letterpress printers, designers, and artists, and they are just as excited as we are about this project!
NEEDED: Beautiful wood type—for everyone
But to make LetterMpress truly beneficial to a creative audience, we need to offer an outstanding collection of authentic wood type and vintage “cuts.” We have a supporter who’s willing to part with a substantial portion of a historic collection purchased from type foundries and print shops when they closed in the ’70s and ’80s.
The amount we need and how we will use the funds: To acquire this collection, we need to raise at least $15,000. Along with these rare, complete collections of wood type, additional funds will also allow us to get help creating the high-resolution photos and scans of the wood type and their corresponding impressions.
The type that we aquire will be housed at a new letterpress co-op called the "Living Letter Press." This co-op will be a resource to designers, artists, students, and anyone interested in learning letterpress.
The end product is just the start
Pricing LetterMpress: We want to make LetterMpress accessible to all, and plan to price it at $5.99 for the base iPad version. We plan to include at least 12 typefaces, and about 50 art "cuts," to which we will add to as we update the app. Pricing for other platforms will be determined by the amount of functionality and size of files generated. Why we need the physical type: Having access to the physical types is a critical part of a later stage* of the LetterMpress venture, which will be to offer authentic letterpress prints from the designs submitted by LetterMpress users. Think about it: Wouldn't it be great to get -real- letterpress prints from your own designs?
Help us make this happen!
With your support, we hope to make LetterMpress a creative resource for designers, artists, students, and anyone who wants to experience the art, craft, and tradition of letterpress.
What you get in return: To show our appreciation for your pledge, we’re offering some great rewards including participation in our beta program, limited edition letterpress art prints, wood type, and the opportunity to name your own typeface in the LetterMpress App.
Check out the list of rewards to see what best suits you. Whatever level you decide, we want to thank you for being part of a growing community that’s committed to keeping the art and craft of letterpress alive.
Thank you for your time!
*This later stage is not part of the initial stage of the LetterMpress project.

updates.update_content:
Hi Again LetterMpress Backers and Friends!
LetterMpress for Mac sailed through the approval process faster than we expected, so we decided to release it today.
As I mentioned in my previous update, you can get the Mac version for $5.99 USD during this first week of sale.

Greetings LetterMpress backers and friends! 
With the successful launch of LetterMpress for iPad this past summer, we were constantly asked if, and when, we would be releasing a version for the Mac.
Once LetterMpress was released, we set to work to see if porting LetterMpress to the Mac was possible.  I’m happy to announce we will be releasing our Mac version in October of 2011.

Greetings LetterMpress Backers and Friends! 
Just a quick update on a few things:
LMP Notoriety:
- We were honored to see that LetterMpress was picked iPad "App of the Week" in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland for the week of July 15th.

P.S. I would rather see kids messing around with this app than playing video games. LetterMpress is as much an educational tool, as it is a design tool. It instills creativity, not destruction, and you can't ask for more. As a designer, I do hope you focus on some real authenticity for output, and I know you will. Signing off now. Enough comments for one day.

@ the nay-sayers ::: In reading the negative comment here—which is rare on Kickstarter—I just want to say, this project will revive the public's interest in the art of letterpress if anything, and may increase business in those currently practicing that trade. I would also call this a public service and a good analogy would be music. There is so much recorded music on vinyl out there which the public will never hear because it's on, well, vinyl. If you take all that music, rip MP3's of it, you suddenly make it accessible and save it from certain doom. This is also true with this project in regards to letterpress type. I thank you for this! And other things could spin out of this, too. How about a working museum which archives and continues to print with letterpress type. The museum could operate as a printer and fund itself through its services. People would also have a place to donate their old "vinyl". Everyone can enjoy it, and it won't be lost. The Virtual Letterpress is a great idea, but the old letterpress will never die either. When we lose our electricity and our petrol we will we also lose our iPads, laser printers, cell phones, cars, and you name it, It will be the 1770's all over again. Horses and letterpress will rule the day, and we can go to museums that display old iPads and laserprints from the LetterMpress app. Cheers!

Congratulations on becoming a funded project. This is an amazing project I am very excited to see. No ipad yet, but perhaps the iPad 2! Good luck on your project. I love letterpress, let me know if you ever need a volunteer! I'm tech savvy and a good people person!

Congratulations on meeting your goal! I posted a blog post about it this morning by coincidence (not having seen it on Tech Crunch): http://pushing-papers.com/2011/03/02/lettermpress-a-virtual-letterpress-on-your-ipad/ This is my first Kickstarter project - am happy to be a backer!

I've seen a lot of Kickstarter projects and hundreds of apps. This project just hits my sweet spot. Wonderful idea and a truly video pitch. I've passed it along to all my advertising friends. Congratulations!

@Michael, you're right that this won't give us the tactile process, just a virtual process. But consider how many who could never have the opportunity for the real experience will now be able to virtually experience an historic process. That's why I think this is a great project, even if you don't agree with the project's other goal for collecting type.
we're owners of a pratt-albion handpress but haven't been working on it much since the kids came... THIS will be a fun way to pass the time!!!

I love the look of this project and will certainly be buying the app for our I-pad once it is released. I could even see using it on my I-phone, since sometimes it's tough to get the family I-pad into my own hands. As a paper crafter, I can see using the app to then create titles for scrapbook pages, especially vintage or retro styled pages, and for greeting cards and journal. You must be pleased at the response and early realization of the goal.

John, this really brings back memories and I'd love a way to show my kids the art of printing pre-Mac. While I decide which level to pledge, would you let us know if we'll be able to select our t-shirt size?

Hi John, just wanted to say that this looks like a really cool project. Haven't done printmaking in a while, but I'm looking forward to using your app. I also went to school at U of I, so it's good seeing great things coming out of Champaign. Good luck.
@John - I'm not a designer at all, but I know a few who would love this kind of app, so I'm supporting your project on principle and curiosity.
I had the chance to test drive this app. When finished, I had to check if I had ink on my fingers. It is an amazing user experience.
Thanks again and good luck.
I was also thinking about how this might work for photopolymer (depending on the size) since photopolymer requires a bitmap output in any case.

"Think about it: Wouldn't it be great to get -real- letterpress prints from your own designs?": We'd be able to design and lock something up on the iPad, and you'd execute this with wood type on a press? This is an extraordinarily interesting idea. It's like remote-telepresence-typesetting. (No offense to the labor that it requires at the shop!)

This sounds awesome--the iPad is the perfect venue for melding the hands-on of letterpress with the ease of digital printing and design. Have you considered including any "lead" type options as well? Wood type is lovely but sometimes you just need a nice Garamond...
Kudos! :)

How would you feel about gifts of novel type to the collection? I've got access to a ShopBot, and would love to be able to letterpress print the calligraphic letters I've been handwriting for years, via your process. On a related note, ShopBot could run off extra copies of any of the letters that you're running low on, or that seem too fragile to keep using.
This is such a fantastic idea! I don't have an iPad either, so can't wait until it's available for Mac.

I hope you will talk to the lovely people at Hamilton Wood Type Museum in Two Rivers, Wisconsin. They have a) an enormous amount of wood type, b) an enormous influence on the design world that's interested in that stuff. Good way to spread the word on wood.

Hi, So I did a smaller sponsor because I wanted to support this, but I do not have an iPad. However if you offer a reward for the android platform (although I know it will come out significantly later than the iPad version) I would up my reward level.

campaign.story:
Thanks for checking out the Alphabet Sea page on Kickstarter. I hope that you will help bring my quirky, whimsical art to an audience of kids eager who are eager to learn to read. With illiteracy on the rise we need to focus on teaching kids to read, and Alphabet Sea is the perfect starter tool. It aids in teaching while being engaging and fun to look at.
Alphabet Sea is a set of Flash cards that will use my hand painted art to illustrate the letters A - Z with fun sea creature names along with fun rhymes to remember them by. They will be limited to 1000 sets and printed on recycled paper for the initial run. The paintings are done on large plywood scraps that I salvage from the desert; upcycling them into one of kind art, instead of littering our planet.
I want to sell enough Flash Card sets to cover print costs of the initial run through pre-selling downloads and sets of the Flash Cards. By ordering a set now you help to launch a new franchise while at the same time saving our future by promoting literacy.
The "Alphabet Sea" Flash Card set makes a great gift, and is a great addition for the active, involved parent.
Thank you for your interest and please, order today!

campaign.story:
Our Orphan Annie isn’t a cute redhead who sings. She’s a big, old cast-iron Monotype Sorts Caster who clicks more than sings, but isn’t doing either at the moment. We want to change that—and we need your help.
Our Orphan Annie was part of the type foundry of the late C. Christopher Stern. Chris inspired many in the letterpress community with his brilliant printing, use of typography and enthusiasm for the craft of hot metal type casting. We’ve moved the foundry to Portland, Oregon and are now in the process of restoring it to working order. In early 2011, we’ll be opening the foundry as a working museum with public programs designed to preserve the craft of casting type, educate, and inspire creativity for a new generation of printers and thing-makers. The Orphan Annie is one of the foundry machines we want to revive.
Our Kickstarter project is to restore the Orphan Annie, record the process, and get her back in the business of casting metal type. We’ll use the money we raise to fund restoration materials and a public space for this industrial machine. We have volunteers to restore and make Orphan Annie sing again, but we also need to ensure she has a stable home and won’t be kicked out into the street. The typeface we’ll cast with her during the inaugural run will be Stern–the typeface created by the legendary typographer Jim Rimmer in honor of Chris Stern (and documented in the Kickstarter-funded film Making Faces). We'll be casting from Jim's original matrices, which he bequeathed to the Type Foundry in 2010. After that, we hope for many tomorrows filled with creative letterpress printing adventures with Orphan Annie and her metal type.
Thanks for your support! The C.C. Stern Type Foundry Board (Brian, Chris, Connie, Jeff, Joe & Rebecca)
P.S. Check out some pictures of our rewards:
One souvenir letter of Stern, cast from Jim Rimmer's matrices on Orphan Annie's inaugural run.
One personalized Ludlow slug cast in Ultra Modern 18 pt., suitable for desk ornamentation or printing with other type-high material.
One composing stick holder to hold a stick of type or your smartphone. This holder is made of die cut, letterpress printed card stock, and will be shipped flat.
A souvenir set of Stern letters, spelling "Thank you!" Because we do!

updates.update_content:
It's hard to believe that we're wrapping up our Orphan Annie project. Thanks to all our backers, we've had an amazing journey restoring our Monotype OA sorts caster. She's now casting type on a regular basis! We've posted the video of the inaugural run and hope you enjoy it.
Orphan Annie Inaugural Run from C.C. Stern Type Foundry on Vimeo.
Backers, we're just wrapping up the last of the rewards, so look for another update on ship dates in the next week or so. Thanks again for all your support!

updates.update_userinfo: The inaugural run video is online
updates.update_content:
She’s hot! And she pumps!
As anyone who’s worked on old machines knows, restoration is rarely a matter of a little cleaning and throwing the switch. On August 6 we tested a pump on the Orphan Annie, but found that it was too worn to provide the pressure needed to cast type. On to Plan B – find and test another pump.

Hello backers. We bring you good news on the Orphan Annie restoration. We've been busy tearing Orphan Annie apart, cleaning her, and getting all her parts back in place and properly adjusted. (Photo below is of Rebecca and Joe adjusting the bridge.)
The cooling unit is partially built. Wiring is in place. The Stern mats have been modified to fit the caster. (Aren't they beautiful?) With all this great actiivity, we're hoping to do the inaugural run of Orphan Annie and begin to cast some on August 6.

Greetings backers and followers from a tired, but happy, Type Foundry board. We held our public open house on Saturday, and had a wonderful turnout with well over 200 people coming by for tours and conversation. With people attending from as far as Seattle and Eugene, families bringing their kids and retirees from the printing trade coming by to chat, we couldn't have hoped for a more fun day--or better validation that this working museum has relevance in our community. We only wish each of you could have been there to see the eagerness and excitement to see these machines running again, to understand how they work and how type metal can be used today.

updates.update_userinfo: Inaugural run date is tentatively set
updates.update_content: Thanks to all 100+ backers so far! We have just 7 days to go, so please tell your friends they still have time to get in on the fun. To entice them and you, here's a peek at the progress on the composition stick holder. And to further entice you Pacific Northwesterners, please come meet Orphan Annie at our open house on Saturday. Willamette Week wrote a nice article about us and the opening, so we hope to have a big crowd.

updates.update_content: Thanks to all the folks who've been volunteering at the Foundry since we started our Kickstarter project! We now have a vent hood on the Orphan Annie (as well as the Material Maker and Composition Caster). We also thought you might like to see what happens at a typical work party... namely cleaning, cataloging and restoring.

updates.update_userinfo: 100+ backers... time for a peek at rewards
updates.update_content:
Hi Backers and followers!
The Foundry will be holding an open house on Saturday, March 26 from 3:00-7:00pm at our museum space in the Greenstreet Details building at 8900 NE Vancouver Way, Portland, Oregon.
We'll be giving tours of the space, showing off the casting equipment and collection of matrices, showing some of Chris Stern's work, and holding a silent auction of donated works including printed ephemera and other handcrafted items.

campaign.story:
Update on film licensing -- Producer/Directors updated 
Another update: Here is a segment that just aired on CBS Evening News: http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/...
Update: Here is a wonderful segment that Chicago Tonight just aired: http://www.wttw.com/chicagotonight/video/A1hO97qcWo7ViDL_rWniVH2LakYxNa7J/
About the Film Finding Vivian Maier - a feature-length documentary
Vivian Maier’s photographs were seemingly destined for obscurity, lost among the clutter of the countless objects she’d collected throughout her life. Instead these images have shocked the world of street photography and irrevocably changed the life of the man who brought them to the public eye. This film brings to life the improbable saga of John Maloof’s discovery of Vivian Maier. Along with her documentary films, photographs, odd collections, and accounts from people who knew her, we take you on the journey of 'Finding Vivian Maier'.
What started as a blog to show her work quickly became a viral sensation in the photography world. Photos destined for the trash heap now line gallery exhibitions, a forthcoming book, and this documentary film. The world wants to know more about Vivian. In order for us to deliver the quality documentary film that we would like to produce, we need funding.
The Status The film is currently in the pre-production stage. We have recently joined forces with an award-winning Danish filmmaker, Lars Oxfeldt Mortensen (www.mortensenfilm.dk). Once we have pre-production financing, we can move forward with the promotional trailer to seek broadcaster financing for the feature-length film we are set out to create.
Funds Monies raised will go to the pre-production budget for the film. This includes equipment, research, trips to conduct interviews and collect footage, editing costs for promotional trailer, and miscellaneous financing. All funds will be used for the film. If we exceed our pre-production budget goal, then all proceeds will go toward the production budget. With your funding help through Kickstarter, we'll be able to move forward on this film with less of a funding hurdle.
It all started here:
http://www.vivianmaier.com
...and here:
http://www.flickr.com/groups/onthestreet/discuss/72157622552378986/
Press Vivian's work has received a considerable amount of press and much more are to come. Here is a list of links to some of the more notable recognition available online:
New York Times LENS: http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/07/new-street-photography-60-years-old/
Chicago Magazine: http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/January-2011/Vivian-Maier-Street-Photographer/
Chicago Sun-Times: http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/2973223-421/maier-maloof-vivian-chicago-negatives.html
NPR's Kitchen Sisters: http://www.kitchensisters.org/girlstories/the-lost-found-photographs-of-vivian-maier/
MIR Appraisals: http://chicagoappraisers.blogspot.com/2010/05/vivian-maier-tribute-part-iv-interview.html
The Design Observer: http://observatory.designobserver.com/entry.html...
The Independent (New Review) in the U.K.: http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/little-miss-big-shot-fifties-america-exposed-ndash-by-a-french-nanny-1811040.html
Repubblica (Italy): http://static.repubblica.it/repubblica/gallerie/gente/foto_america/index.html
Clarin (Argentina): http://www.clarin.com/diario/2009/10/22/um/m-02024494.htm
Clarin also (neat slideshow): http://www.revistaenie.clarin.com/notas/2010/02/03/_-02132908.htm
Danish news: http://kpn.dk/article1871460.ece
Thank you for your time. Your generous contributions will aid in our efforts to assure a lasting appreciation of Vivian Maier's art, and presenting this story to the world.
Kind regards,
John Maloof Anthony Rydzon
